title: In the Matter of Ettel v. State
description: In this sexually violent predator case, the Court of Appeals held the circuit court properly permitted an expert to testify at the defendant's commitment trial regarding prior sexually-related offenses not resulting in convictions as well as to a prior murder conviction on the grounds that the prejudicial nature of this evidence did not outweigh its probative value.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of
  Appeals

	
		
			
				In the Matter of the Care and Treatment of James P. Ettel, Appellant,
				v.
				The State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
L. Casey Manning,
  Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4364
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed April 1, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Assistant
  Appellate Defender Lanelle C. Durant, South Carolina Office of Appellate
  Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster,
  Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Attorney General
  Deborah R. J. Shupe, and Assistant Attorney General R. Westmoreland Clarkson,
  all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.: James Ettel (Ettel) claims
  the circuit court erred in permitting an expert to testify at his commitment
  trial regarding prior sexually-related offenses that did not result in
  convictions and to a prior murder conviction.Â  Ettel argues the prejudicial
  nature of this evidence substantially outweighed its probative value.Â  We
  affirm.Â   
FACTS
On July 30, 1990, Ettel pled guilty to
  criminal sexual conduct in the first degree and assault and battery of a high
  and aggravated nature.Â  Ettel was sentenced to concurrent terms of thirty years
  and ten years, respectively.Â   
Ettelâ€™s conviction stemmed out of a
  sexual assault in which he bound and gagged the victim, choked and beat her,
  and then forced the victim to perform oral sex on him after raping her. Â Ettel
  had known the victim on a casual basis for two months prior to the attack as he
  frequented a club where she worked as a bartender.Â  The night of the attack,
  Ettel told the victim he was too intoxicated to drive home and asked her for a
  ride to his apartment.Â  Once she entered his apartment, Ettel forced her onto
  the couch and stated he would cut her into pieces if she did not remain
  silent.Â  Ettel drove the victim back to his car the next morning after she told
  him she would not tell the police.Â   
Before Ettelâ€™s release from prison for the criminal
  sexual conduct conviction, the State filed a petition for Ettelâ€™s civil
  commitment pursuant to the Sexually Violent Predator Act[1] (SVP Act).Â  The circuit court found probable cause to believe Ettel was a
  sexually violent predator and ordered a probable cause hearing.Â  At the
  hearing, the circuit court ordered Ettel to undergo a psychiatric evaluation,
  which was performed by Dr. Pamela Crawford, M.D., (Dr. Crawford) a forensic
  psychiatrist with the Department of Mental Health.Â Â   
During Dr. Crawfordâ€™s interview
  with Ettel, Ettel admitted to three sexual offenses that did not result in
  convictions.Â  The first offense occurred when Ettel worked at an appliance
  store in Michigan and grabbed a customerâ€™s breasts and attempted to kiss her.Â 
  He was charged with assault and intent to commit gross indecency and
  kidnapping, but he was found not guilty.Â  The second offense pertained to an
  incident when Ettel kidnapped a hitchhiker in Montana, took her to his house
  against her will, and tried to grope her breasts.Â  He was charged with sexual
  misconduct, but the charges were subsequently dropped.Â  The third offense
  occurred at an animal hospital in Montana when Ettel attempted to sexually
  assault a woman who worked at the hospital.Â  He was charged with sexual intercourse
  without consent, but these charges were dropped when he was extradited to South Carolina for the sexual assault on the bartender.Â  Based on Dr. Crawfordâ€™s
  evaluation, she concluded Ettel suffered from the mental abnormality of
  paraphilia, not otherwise specified, and had a history of extreme violence,
  which made it likely he would engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined
  for long-term control, care, and treatment under the SVP Act.Â   
Before trial, Ettelâ€™s counsel moved to exclude any
  testimony regarding the sexual offenses that did not result in convictions as
  well as evidence regarding Ettelâ€™s prior murder conviction.[2]Â 
  Dr. Crawford testified in camera about the evidence supporting
  her opinion, and the circuit court denied Ettelâ€™s motion to exclude the
  evidence.Â  At trial, Dr. Crawford testified about her conclusions from Ettelâ€™s
  evaluation and discussed the disputed evidence to support her findings.Â  Based
  on the evidence, the jury found Ettel satisfied the definition of a sexually
  violent predator, and Ettel was sentenced to long-term commitment under the SVP
  Act.Â   
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ettel claims the circuit court committed
  reversible error when it permitted Dr. Crawford to testify about his previous
  sexual offenses that did not result in convictions and his previous murder
  conviction.Â  Ettel claims the prejudicial effect of the evidence substantially
  outweighed its probative value.Â  We disagree.
The admission of evidence is within
  the discretion of the circuit court and will not be reversed absent an abuse of
  discretion. Â In re Corley, 353 S.C. 202, 205, 577 S.E.2d 451, 453
  (2003). Â Generally, all relevant evidence is admissible. Â Rule 402, SCRE; State
    v. Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 578, 647 S.E.2d 144, 170 (2007).Â  Evidence is
  relevant if it tends to establish or make more or less probable the matter in
  controversy. Â Rule 401, SCRE. Â However, relevant evidence may be excluded if
  the danger of unfair prejudice substantially outweighs its probative value. Â Rule
  403, SCRE.
Under the SVP Act, a sexually violent predator is
  defined as a person who (a) has been convicted of a sexually violent offense
  and (b) suffers from a mental abnormality or personality disorder that makes
  the person likely to engage in acts of sexual violence if not confined in a
  secure facility for long-term control, care, and treatment. Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  44-48-30(1)(a), (b) (Supp. 2007).
After the State files a petition to
  request a probable cause hearing, the circuit court must make a probable cause
  determination as to whether the person is a sexually violent predator.Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-70, -80(A) (Supp. 2007).Â  If the probable cause
  determination is made, the person must undergo an evaluation by a
  court-approved expert as to whether the person is a sexually violent predator.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-80(D) (Supp. 2007).Â  Experts are allowed to have
  â€œreasonable access to the person for the purpose of the examination, as well as
  access to all relevant medical, psychological, criminal offense,
  and disciplinary records and reports.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-48-90 (Supp. 2007) (emphasis
  added).
These offenses can include both
  convictions and offenses not resulting in convictions as long as they are
  relevant to the determination of whether a person is a sexually violent
  predator.Â  See White v. State, 375 S.C. 1, 9, 649 S.E.2d 172, 176
  (Ct. App. 2007) (holding past convictions and prior offenses not resulting in
  convictions that bear on whether a person is a sexually violent predator are
  admissible in a SVP case).Â  Because a â€œpersonâ€™s dangerous propensities are the
  focus of the SVP Act,â€ consideration of â€œ[p]ast criminal history is therefore
  directly relevant to establishing 44-48-30(1)(a),â€ which in turn bears directly
  on whether one suffers from a mental abnormality under section 44-48-30(1)(b).Â  In re Corley, 353 S.C. at 206-07, 577 S.E.2d at 453-54.Â  
 
The circuit court properly admitted Dr. Crawfordâ€™s
  testimony regarding Ettelâ€™s prior sexual offenses as well as his prior murder
  conviction. Â The prior sexual offenses and the murder conviction were
  relevant because Dr. Crawford relied on them in evaluating Ettelâ€™s need for and
  likelihood of success in treatment as well as his ability to control his
  behavior in the future.Â  See State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557,
  564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002) (holding admission of motion did not violate
  defendantâ€™s due process rights because it was relevant in evaluating
  defendantâ€™s need for and probability of success in treatment and was not
  unfairly prejudicial as it was one of several sources on which the expert based
  her opinion); see also Rule 401, SCRE (â€œâ€˜Relevant evidenceâ€™ means
  evidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of
  consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable
  than it would be without the evidence.â€).Â   
Looking at Ettelâ€™s prior sexual
  offenses established a â€œpattern of behavior of sexual assaults,â€ and this
  pattern was significant because as Dr. Crawford stated, â€œ[F]uture behavior [can
  only be predicted] based on past behavior.â€Â  Additionally, the murder
  conviction was relevant due to the crimeâ€™s level of violence.Â  Dr. Crawford
  stated, â€œWhether or not [the murder] was a sexual crime . . . it goes to
  [Ettelâ€™s] propensity to commit further violent crimes.â€Â  Based on the
  officersâ€™ recollection of the crimes, Dr. Crawford learned â€œthere may have been
  a sexual motivation in [the] crime,â€ which would aid in her diagnosis. Â Â 
Further, the possibility of unfair
  prejudice did not substantially outweigh the probative value of the testimony. Â Regarding
  its probative value, Dr. Crawford used the information to develop her â€œopinion
  in terms of [Ettel] not being able to control his behaviorâ€ and to diagnose
  Ettel with paraphilia.Â  As for the testimonyâ€™s possible prejudice, the
  prior sexual offenses not resulting in convictions as well as the murder
  conviction were not the only sources of Dr. Crawfordâ€™s diagnosis.Â  Dr. Crawford
  testified that even without considering this evidence, her opinion as to
  whether Ettel had a mental abnormality or personality disorder would not
  change.Â  Dr. Crawford stated she additionally relied on, among other sources,
  Ettelâ€™s past criminal sexual conduct conviction, Ettelâ€™s statements during her
  extensive clinical forensic interviews with him, interviews with individuals
  close to Ettel, administrative records, Ettelâ€™s prior psychological evaluation,
  and his record while in a sex offender treatment program.Â   
Because Dr. Crawfordâ€™s testimony regarding
  Ettelâ€™s prior sexual offenses not resulting in convictions and previous murder
  conviction was relevant and the probative value outweighed any prejudicial
  effect, the circuit court acted within its discretion and properly admitted the
  testimony.Â  See Gaster, 349 S.C. at 557, 564 S.E.2d at 94 (finding
  disputed evidence was relevant and its probative value outweighed any
  prejudicial effect such that circuit court properly admitted the evidence
  within its discretion).Â   
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the circuit
  courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.[3] 
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. 


[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 44-48-10 to -170 (Supp. 2007).
[2] In 1962, Ettel was convicted in Michigan of murdering
  his girlfriendâ€™s mother with a pair of sewing scissors.Â  Dr. Crawford testified
  the arresting officers told her the motherâ€™s shirt was pulled above the
  motherâ€™s head, and Ettel allegedly told the officers he tried to sexually
  assault the mother before he killed the mother.Â  No incident report was
  available for Dr. Crawford to substantiate the officersâ€™ testimony.Â   
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Isiah James,
      Jr., Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services (SCDPPPS), Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Administrative Law Court
Â Ralph King Anderson, III, Administrative
  Law Judge
Opinion No. 4365
Submitted February 1, 2008 â€“ Filed April
  1, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Isiah James, Jr., Pro se,
  for Appellant.
				J. Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Isiah
  James, Jr. appeals the Administrative Law Courtâ€™s (ALC) dismissal of his appeal
  for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.Â   
FACTS
On
  June 18, 1979, James pled guilty to two counts of voluntary manslaughter and
  armed robbery.Â  The trial judge sentenced him to two, thirty-year consecutive
  terms of imprisonment for each count of voluntary manslaughter, and a
  twenty-five-year consecutive term of imprisonment for armed robbery.Â   
James
  first became eligible for parole in 1988, and the South Carolina Board of
  Probation, Parole and Pardon Services (Board) rejected his application.Â  Over
  the years, the Board rejected Jamesâ€™ parole several more times.Â  In 2005, James
  filed a request for the Board to reconsider his most recent parole rejection.Â 
  In this request for reconsideration, James asserted his due process rights were
  violated because only five of the seven board members were present for his
  hearing.Â  The Board denied his request for rehearing, finding â€œthe reasons
  stated in [Jamesâ€™] request did not affect the decision of the Parole Board.â€Â  Thereafter,
  James appealed to the ALC, asserting once more that his due process rights were
  violated.Â  The ALC dismissed his appeal due to a lack of subject matter
  jurisdiction.Â  This appeal followed.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Section
  1-23-610 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) sets forth the standard of
  review when the court of appeals is sitting in review of a decision by the ALC
  on an appeal from an administrative agency.Â  â€œThe review of the administrative
  law judgeâ€™s order must be confined to the record.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  1-23-610(C) (Supp. 2006). Â The court of appeals may reverse or modify the
  decision only if substantive rights of the appellant have been prejudiced
  because the decision is clearly erroneous in light of the reliable and
  substantial evidence on the whole record, arbitrary or otherwise characterized
  by an abuse of discretion, or affected by other error of law.Â  Id.Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
James argues the ALC erred in dismissing his appeal on the grounds
  that it lacked subject matter jurisdiction.Â  We agree that the ALC has subject
  matter jurisdiction over all inmate grievances, but also affirm that Jamesâ€™
  appeal should have been dismissed.  
Our supreme court recently offered clarification of Al-Shabazz
  v. State[1] and its progeny as to an ALCâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction in Furtick v.
    South Carolina Department of Corrections, 374 S.C. 334, 649 S.E.2d 35
  (2007).[2] Â In Furtick, the court reemphasized its clarification of jurisdiction in Slezak v. South Carolina Dept. of Corrections, stating â€œthe ALC has
  jurisdiction over all inmate grievance appeals that have been properly
  filed; the ALC however, is not required to hold a hearing in every matter.â€Â  Id. at 340, 649 S.E.2d at 38 (emphasis in original) (explaining Slezak v. South
    Carolina Dept. of Corrections, 361 S.C. 327, 605 S.E.2d 506 (2004)).Â  The
  court continues that the ALC could summarily dismiss any appeal where the
  inmateâ€™s grievance does not implicate a state-created liberty or property
  interest.Â  Id.Â   
Although the ALC had subject matter jurisdiction to hear Jamesâ€™
  claim, his appeal does not implicate a state created liberty or property
  interest and therefore dismissal was appropriate.Â  In determining the existence
  of a liberty interest, â€œan inmate has the
  right of review by the [ALC] after the final decision that he is ineligible for parole, but . . . a parole-eligible inmate does not have the same right of
  review after the decision denying parole . . . This distinction stems from the
  fact that parole is a privilege, not a right.â€
  Â Sullivan v. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 355 S.C. 437, 586 S.E.2d 124 n.4 (2003) (emphasis in original). Â In the case before
  us, the Board denied Jamesâ€™ parole, but did not permanently deny his
  eligibility; therefore his grievance does not implicate a liberty or property
  interest.
Moreover, the inquiry into whether an inmate is entitled to review
  of a parole boardâ€™s final decision is based on whether the inmate â€œhas a
  liberty interest in gaining access to the parole board.â€Â  Furtick v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Probation, Parole & Pardon Services., 352 S.C. 594, 598, 576
  S.E.2d 146, 149 (2003).Â  As previously illustrated, Jamesâ€™ appeal does not
  involve any liberty interest, and he consequently has no right to a review of
  the Boardâ€™s decision.  
James
  next asserts that because the Parole Board conducted its hearing with only five
  of the seven members present and voting, it denied him a right to a hearing
  altogether.Â  We disagree.
James
  submitted this argument to the ALC on appeal, but the ALCâ€™s order did not
  address the issue in its order.Â  Thereafter, James made no Rule 59(e), SCRCP,
  motion to alter or amend the proposed order, and under this courtâ€™s general
  preservation rules, this argument would not be preserved for our review.Â  See Great Games, Inc. v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Revenue, 339 S.C. 79, 529
  S.E.2d 6 (2000) (stating where a party raises an issue, the trial court fails
  to rule upon the issue, and the party fails to raise the courtâ€™s omission by
  way of a Rule 59 motion, the issue is not ruled upon and, therefore, not
  preserved on appeal).Â  We note the issue of whether a Rule 59(e) motion is
  necessary, or even cognizable to an ALC is one that has not been decided in South Carolina.Â  Pursuant to this courtâ€™s request for certification, this precise issue is
  now pending before the South Carolina Supreme Court.Â  Assuming without deciding
  that a Rule 59(e) motion is not necessary to an ALC in order to preserve an
  issue on appeal, and in the interests of judicial economy, we will address the
  merits of Jamesâ€™ contention.
Chapter
  21 of Title 24 of the South Carolina Code (2007) provides the statutory framework
  for the Board of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services.Â  However, Chapter 21
  does not specify the exact number of board members that must be present for a
  parole hearing.Â  The chairperson of the Parole Board may direct the board
  members to meet in three-person panels, and any unanimous vote of a panel is
  considered a final decision of the board.Â  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-30(A) (2007).Â  In order to grant parole of a violent crime as
  defined in Section 16-1-60, under which Jamesâ€™ guilty pleas to voluntary
  manslaughter and armed robbery fall, a two-thirds majority vote of the full
  board is required.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-30(B) (2007); See also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-1-60 (2007).Â  Conversely, the statute does not require a certain
  number of board members to be present in order to deny parole for someone
  convicted of a violent crime.Â   
â€œIn
  the absence of any statutory or other controlling provision, the common-law
  rule that a majority of the whole board is necessary to constitute a quorum
  applies, and the board may do no valid act in the absence of a
  quorum.â€Â  Garris v. Governing Bd. of the State Reinsurance Facility, 333
  S.C. 432, 453, 511 S.E.2d 48, 59 (1998).Â  Here, five members of the Board were
  present, and each voted to deny Jamesâ€™ parole.Â  A unanimous and majority
  decision was reached by a quorum in this hearing; thus Jamesâ€™ contention is
  without merit.  
CONCLUSION
Although
  we agree the ALC has subject matter jurisdiction over all inmate grievances, no
  liberty interest was implicated in this case and James was not entitled to an
  appeal.Â  Consequently, the ALC did not err in dismissing his case.Â  The ALCâ€™s
  order is accordingly
AFFIRMED.[3] Â 
PIEPER,
  J., and GOOLSBY, A.J., concur.

[1] Al-Shabazz
  v. State, 338 S.C. 354,
527 S.E.2d 742 (2000).
[2] We acknowledge that the ALCâ€™s Order of Dismissal was
  filed July 19, 2006, and was therefore decided without the benefit of Furtick v. South Carolina Department of
    Corrections, 374 S.C.
334, 649 S.E.2d 35 (2007).
[3] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Allan S. Terry Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control,
  Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management, and South Carolina Department
  of Archives and History Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Coastal
  Zone Management Appellate Panel
Office of Ocean
  and Coastal Resource Management
South Carolina Department of Health and
  Environmental Control
Opinion No. 4366
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed April 3,
  2008 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				C. C. Harness, III, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellant.
				Carlisle Roberts, Jr., of Columbia, Evander Whitehead, of Charleston, and James S. Chandler, Jr., of Pawleyâ€™s Island, for Respondents.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â Â Â Â  Allan S. Terry (Landowner) appeals the decision of the Coastal
  Zone Management Appellate Panel (Appellate Panel) affirming the order of the
  Administrative Law Court (ALC) which upheld the Office of Ocean and Coastal
  Resource Managementâ€™s (OCRM) denial of his application for a recreational dock
  permit.Â  We affirm.  
FACTS
In June
  1991, Tamsburg Properties (Developer) applied to the Coastal Council for a
  permit to install ten private docks, one community dock, and a community boat
  ramp within Bakers Landing, a proposed residential subdivision in Dorchester County along the shoreline of the Ashley River.[1]Â 
  Developerâ€™s application to build multiple docks generated controversy among the
  interested parties, and extensive discussions took place involving OCRM staff,
  Developer, and public agencies.Â  A public hearing on the application was also
  held.Â  During this same time, planning was underway to create a Special Area
  Management Plan (SAMP) to conserve the
  natural and historic character of the Ashley River corridor, an area that now includes
  the Bakers Landing subdivision.Â   
On February 6, 1992, Coastal Councilâ€™s Permitting Committee issued
  a permit to Developer authorizing installation of eight private docks and one
  community dock.Â  The Coastal Council conditioned the permit upon Developerâ€™s
  agreement to the following conditions: a community boat ramp would not be
  built; the community dock would not be used for permanent moorage; pier heads
  would not be located over wetlands vegetation; and no additional docks or modifications
  to permitted docks would be allowed within the boundaries of the subdivision.Â  Because
  there was no appeal of OCRMâ€™s issuance of this permit to Developer, it became a
  final agency decision.Â   
In 1998, Landowner purchased a lot in Bakers Landing that bordered
  a tributary of the Ashley River.[2]Â 
  In 2002, he applied for a permit to construct a dock.Â  Based on the pre-existing, special conditions permit OCRM issued to Developer in 1992, OCRM denied Landownerâ€™s permit application in a letter dated August 9, 2002, which stated: 
 

	OCRM,
  in its 1991 review of a multiple dock application made by the developers of
  Bakers Landing, Tamsberg Properties (91-3D-185-P), conditionally limited the
  development to 8 private docks and 1 community use dock, to which [D]eveloper
  agreed.Â  The 1991 general dock permit served as the Dock Master Plan for all
  docks within the Bakers Landing Development, and consequently must be used as a
  framework for subsequent permitting decisions.Â  The [Landownerâ€™s] application
  goes against the terms of the [Developerâ€™s] permit and is a piecemeal attempt
  to permit additional docks where OCRM has already acted.Â  Therefore, OCRM staff
  has determined that this application must be denied.

Landowner requested a contested case hearing before the Administrative
  Law Court (ALC).[3] Â The ALC upheld OCRMâ€™s denial of the permit application, and Landowner appealed
  to the Appellate Panel.Â  The Appellate Panel found no error of law and held
  that substantial evidence in the record supported the ALCâ€™s decision. Â This
  appeal followed.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW [4]
In administrative law cases, the ALC serves as the
  fact-finder and is not restricted by the findings of the administrative
  agency.Â  Dorman v. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control, 350 S.C. 159,
  164, 565 S.E.2d 119, 122 (Ct. App. 2002); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-600(A)-(B)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  An aggrieved party may appeal the ALCâ€™s decision to the agencyâ€™s
  Appellate Panel; however, the Panelâ€™s review is confined to the record and is
  governed by South Carolina Code section 1-23-610(C).Â  Accordingly, the
  Appellate Panel can reverse the ALCâ€™s decision if it determines the ALCâ€™s
  findings are not supported by substantial evidence contained in the record or
  are affected by an error of law. Â Dorman at 165, 565 S.E.2d at 122; see also Grant v. S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 353, 461
  S.E.2d 388, 391 (1995) (stating the ALCâ€™s findings are supported by substantial
  evidence if, looking at the record as a whole, there is evidence from which
  reasonable minds could reach the same conclusion the ALC reached).  
After an aggrieved party has
  exhausted all administrative remedies, the party is entitled to judicial review
  by the South Carolina Court of Appeals.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§1-23-380(A)
  (Supp. 2007).Â  Judicial review is confined to the record and is governed by
  South Carolina Code section Â§1-23-380 (A)(5), which provides: 

	The
  court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency as to the
  weight of the evidence on questions of fact. Â The court may affirm the decision
  of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings. Â [However,] [t]he
  court may reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant
  have been prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences,
  conclusions, or decisions are: (a) in violation
  of constitutional or statutory provisions; (b) in excess of the statutory 
	authority of the agency; (c) made upon unlawful procedure; (d) affected
  by other error of law; (e) clearly erroneous in
  view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record;
  or (f) arbitrary or capricious or characterized
  by abuse of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.

LAW/ANALYSIS
A.Â 1992 Permit as a
  Basis for OCRMâ€™s Denial 
Landowner argues
  the basis for OCRMâ€™s denial of his application for a dock permit was improper.Â 
  We disagree.  
First,
  Landowner contends OCRM improperly denied his application because regulations
  controlling Dock Master Plans (DMPs) did not exist when OCRM issued a permit to
  Developer in 1992. Â Richard Chinnas, who served as Coastal Councilâ€™s permitting
  coordinator in 1992, testified the Council began implementing a comprehensive
  approach to dock master planning in 1987 under its general permitting
  authority.Â  At that time, the Coastal Council authorized multiple dock permits,
  which it characterized as â€œDMPs,â€ although the process governing DMPs was not
  formalized until 1993.Â  Chinnas testified the Coastal Councilâ€™s permitting
  authority allowed it to issue Developer a permit prohibiting installation of
  additional docks and the permit continued to be enforceable, whether it was
  called a DMP or a general permit.[5]Â  
 
Our
  review of the record shows substantial evidence supports the ALCâ€™s finding that
  OCRM properly denied Landownerâ€™s permit application based on the special
  provisions contained in the permit the Coastal Council issued to Developer in
  1992.Â   
B.Â Evaluation of
  Permit Application on its Merits
Landowner
  argues OCRM failed to consider his permit application on its individual merits and
  contends Developerâ€™s permit expired in 1995.Â  We disagree.
OCRMâ€™s
  letter of August 9, 2002 stated the basis for denying Landownerâ€™s permit
  application was the 1992 permit issued to Developer, which was conditioned upon
  there being no additional docks in the subdivision.Â  OCRMâ€™s letter also
  indicated the statutes and regulations it relied upon in denying Landownerâ€™s
  application.Â   
The
  ALCâ€™s order stated its decision to uphold OCRMâ€™s denial of the permit was based
  on the unique facts of this case, and upon:

	overriding
  considerations flowing from Regs. 30-11(C)(1) (the need to consider the extent
  to which long-range, cumulative effects of the project may result within the
  context of other possible development and the general character of the area)
  and Regs. 30-11(C)(2) (the need to consider the extent to which the overall
  plans and designs can be submitted together and evaluated as a whole, rather
  than submitted piecemeal and in aÂ  fragmented way which limits comprehensive
  review).Â  

The ALC concluded granting
  Landownerâ€™s permit application was â€œsimply incompatibleâ€ with the consideration
  owed these regulations.  
Chinnas
  testified the Coastal Council issued dock permits containing special conditions
  when it was possible to review all potential impacts at the time a new
  development was proposed in order to avoid future â€œpiecemealâ€ applications.Â  He
  stated this type of permit â€œgave us the opportunity to cumulatively review the
  whole project, essentially lock the project inâ€ when the proposed development
  was â€œstill a piece of raw land.â€Â  Chinnas also testified the permitâ€™s
  expiration date governs only the construction period and the conditions remain
  enforceable until they are amended.Â   
We
  find substantial evidence in the record supports the ALCâ€™s finding that OCRM reviewed
  Landownerâ€™s application on its individual merits, yet within the context of the
  1992 permit prohibiting additional docks.
C.Â Ashley River SAMP
On
  appeal to this court, Landowner asks us to consider the specific policies of
  the Ashley River SAMP.[6]Â 
  However, OCRMâ€™s letter denying Landownerâ€™s permit application, the ALCâ€™s
  decision, and the Appellate Panelâ€™s ruling each stated the permitâ€™s denial was
  based upon the original dock plan issued to Developer in 1992 and on
  consideration of the applicable regulations; the orders did not address the
  SAMP policies.Â  Accordingly, this issue is not preserved for our review.Â  See Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t. of Health and Envtl.
    Control, 348 S.C. 507, 519, 560
  S.E.2d 410, 417 (2002) (â€œ[I]ssues not raised to and ruled on by the agency are
  not preserved for judicial consideration.Â  Likewise, issues not raised to and
  ruled on by the ALJ are not preserved for appellate consideration.â€).  
D.Â Subsequent Events 
Landowner
  contends the special conditions contained in OCRMâ€™s 1992 permit are â€œrendered
  moot by multiple amendments.â€Â  We disagree.  
A
  review of the record shows OCRM had allowed some minor changes to be made to
  the nine docks constructed under Developerâ€™s 1992 permit; these changes include
  the addition of safety rails, navigation lights, and benches to the existing
  docks.Â  Yet, the record also shows OCRM denied several applications to modify
  existing docks, and some dock owners had modified their docks without seeking a
  permit.Â   
Chinnas
  testified the ALC authorized one additional dock under a consent order to
  resolve confusion related to the placement of a joint dock under the 1992
  permit.Â  However, he also stated the ALCâ€™s consent order did not constitute a
  modification to the permitâ€™s special condition prohibiting additional docks.Â  
 
The
  ALCâ€™s order expressly addressed both subsequent modifications to existing docks
  and the ALCâ€™s consent order authorizing one additional dock; however, the ALC
  dismissed Landownerâ€™s argument as unpersuasive:  

	I have
  given consideration to the fact that modifications have occurred to the
  existing docks and that at least one dock has been added beyond the nine
  originally authorized.Â  However, the addition of handrails to many docks has
  resulted from safety concerns and the other modifications have not been
  extensive.Â  Further, only one new dock added since the original dock plan was
  issued was a dock which arose due to extenuating circumstances.Â  Even that dock
  was not allowed until a consent order was executed through the ALC.Â  Thus, there
  is no evidence of wholesale additions of docks to the subdivision.Â 
  Accordingly, the denial of [Landownerâ€™s] dock is not inconsistent with the past
  practice of OCRM in Bakers Landing.

Chinnas
  testified Bakers Landing has ten waterfront lots that are currently restricted
  from building docks by Developerâ€™s 1992 permit.Â  The Homeownerâ€™s Association
  stated in a letter to OCRM that if it granted Landownerâ€™s application â€œequity
  would require that all properties in Bakers Landing that border on the river or
  marsh should be granted permits upon application.â€Â   
We
  agree with the ALCâ€™s conclusion that minor modifications to the nine permitted
  docks and a consent order allowing the addition of one dock during the fifteen
  years following issuance of Developerâ€™s permit is not sufficient to warrant
  alteration of the conditions OCRM placed on the 1992 permit.  
CONCLUSION
We
  find the final order of the ALC was unaffected by an error of law and that substantial
  evidence in the record supports its order upholding OCRMâ€™s denial of
  Landownerâ€™s application for a dock permit.Â  Accordingly, the final order of the
  Appellate Panel is
AFFIRMED.[7]
PIEPER,
  J., and CURETON, A.J., concur. 

[1] The South Carolina Coastal Council was subsequently
  incorporated into OCRM within the Department of Health and Environmental
  Control (DHEC).Â   
[2] In documents Landowner filed with his dock permit
  application, he stated he paid the fair market value of $65,000 for his lot in
  1998. Â 
[3] The South Carolina Department of Archives and History
  intervened in support of OCRMâ€™s denial of Landownerâ€™s dock permit, contending â€œthe
  proposed dock would cause undue adverse impacts on the historical and cultural
  values of the Ashley River Historic District, would be inconsistent with the
  Ashley River Special Area Management Plan, and thus would violate the Coastal
  Zone Management Act and the OCRM regulations.â€Â   
[4] The procedural posture of this case is unique because
  the ALC and the Appellate Panel heard Landownerâ€™s appeal prior to the passage
  of 2006 Act No. 387, which was enacted to provide a uniform procedure for hearing
  contested cases and appeals from administrative agencies.Â  Act 387 became
  effective on July 1, 2006 and amended the South Carolina Code sections
  referenced in this opinion. Â See 2006 Act No. 387.
[5] In our review of the record, we note the Coastal
  Councilâ€™s 1991 minutes referred to its consideration of a â€œdock master planâ€
  for Bakers Landing.Â   
[6] On February 14, 1992, this section of the river was
  designated as being within the SAMP.Â  Chinnas testified the Coastal Councilâ€™s decision
  to issue a special conditions permit to Developer was not driven by SAMP and,
  in fact, had SAMP been the driving factor in its decision, the resulting permit
  would have granted only one dock.Â   
[7] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.Â

description: Jaleel V. Page appeals his convictions for conspiracy, attempted armed robbery, and possession of a pistol by a person under the age of 21.  Page contends the circuit court erred in allowing the State to introduce evidence that a nontestifying co-defendant implicated Page in a statement to police where the statement did not fall into a hearsay objection, and Pageâ€™s counsel did not â€œopen the doorâ€ to the admission of the statement. THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Jaleel V. Page, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Marc H. Westbrook, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4367
  Heard December 12, 2007 â€“ Filed April 3,
2008

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, South Carolina Commission
          on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
          Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, Office of the Attorney General, of
          Columbia; I. McDuffie Stone, III, Solicitor, Fourteenth Judicial Circuit
          Solicitorâ€™s Office, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Jaleel
  V. Page appeals his convictions for conspiracy, attempted armed robbery, and
  possession of a pistol by a person under the age of 21.Â  Page contends the
  circuit court erred in allowing the State to introduce evidence that a
  nontestifying co-defendant implicated Page in a statement to police where the
  statement did not fall into a hearsay exception, and Pageâ€™s counsel did not
  â€œopen the doorâ€ to the admission of the statement.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On March 16, 2003, Willie Cunningham (Victim)
  was shot and killed near his home in York, South Carolina.Â  Katrina Howard (Girlfriend)
  testified she had driven Page and Lamont McCollum to York that day to the Hall
  Street Apartments.[1] Â Upon arriving in York, Page and McCollum gathered with a group of approximately
  eight individuals in a park near the apartments.Â  Both Page and McCollum showed
  the group, which included co-defendants A.J. Williams and Terrence McKnight, a
  gun each was carrying.Â  The group was smoking marijuana and discussing â€œmaking
  a lick,â€ which Williams testified was slang for â€œcoming up on some extra money,
  doing something to come up with some extra money some way or somehow.â€Â  
Rashad Simpson (Nephew), Victimâ€™s nephew, lived with Victim at the
  time of the murder. Â Nephew testified that on the same afternoon he was
  approached by Page and McCollum, neither of whom he knew, asking where they could
  buy marijuana.Â  Nephew responded in the negative and walked away.Â  Later that
  afternoon, the group, led principally by McCollum and Page, concocted a plan to
  rob Victimâ€™s trailer while Nephew was away.Â  McCollum indicated that if
  Williams and McKnight served as lookouts, they â€œwould get a cut of whatever
  [McCollum and Page took] from [Victim]â€™s house.â€Â  Shortly thereafter, the group
  of four approached Victimâ€™s trailer. Â McCollum and Page went directly to the
  porch, and Williams testified he and McKnight stood off to the side of the
  trailer.Â  Before McCollum and Page could go inside, Victim came to the door of
  his trailer.Â  A discussion ensued, and Williams saw Victim reach for the gun
  that McCollum had pulled out of his pocket.Â  Then, Williams testified, McCollum
  â€œpulled back the gun . . . and shot him two times in the chest.â€Â  
None of the four participants came immediately forward to the police.Â 
  Instead, Williams was first caught on tape some nine months later describing Victimâ€™s
  death to a fellow inmate who was wearing a wire, while both were incarcerated
  on other charges.Â  Williams thereafter gave a full statement to Detective Sara
  Robbins (Detective).Â  At the time of his arrest, McKnight gave police an oral
  statement that was later memorialized in writing, as well as a second written
  statement implicating himself and the other co-defendants.Â  In addition,
  Girlfriend gave a statement conflicting with that of Williams, putting both
  McCollum and Page on Nephewâ€™s porch, but indicating Page was the one who shot Victim.Â  
Page made a pre-trial motion to suppress the statements implicating
  him if McKnight chose not to testify, but the motion was denied.Â  At trial, a
  redacted version of McKnightâ€™s statement, replacing any mention of Page with
  â€œanother guyâ€ or the â€œother guy,â€ was admitted into evidence over Pageâ€™s
  objection.Â  McKnight was present at the trial, but chose not to testify.Â  McKnightâ€™s
  statements confirm that both McCollum and Page had guns on the day in question,
  and were interested in robbing Victimâ€™s trailer.Â  
On cross-examination, Page questioned Detective extensively about her
  investigation and the steps leading to the charges and ultimate arrests of
  Page, McCollum, and McKnight.[2]Â 
  Pageâ€™s cross-examination of Detective attempted to show how the State had very
  little evidence to link Page to the murder and attempted armed robbery.Â  Thereafter,
  the State made a motion to admit McKnightâ€™s full and complete statement on the
  basis Page had opened the door to allow the unredacted evidence.Â  The circuit
  court agreed, and admitted McKnightâ€™s unredacted statement. Â 
The jury found Page guilty of conspiracy, attempted armed robbery,
  and possession of a pistol by a person under the age of 21. Â Page was found not
  guilty of murder. Â This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The admission of
  evidence is within the discretion of the trial court and will not be reversed
  absent an abuse of discretion. Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564
  S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the conclusions of
  the trial court either lack evidentiary support or are controlled by an error
  of law. Â State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 325, 540 S.E.2d 464, 467
  (2000).Â  In criminal cases, the appellate
  court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Butler, 353 S.C. 383,
  388, 577 S.E.2d 498, 500 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We are bound by the trial
  courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  Id.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Page asserts the circuit court erred in finding
  his counsel had â€œopened the doorâ€ to the admission of the unredacted statement
  of his nontestifying co-defendant.Â  We disagree and affirm.Â  
â€œThe constitutional
  right to confront and cross examine witnesses is essential to a fair trial in
  that it promotes reliability in criminal trials and insures [sic] that
  convictions will not result from testimony of individuals who cannot be
  challenged at trial.â€ Â State v. Martin, 292 S.C. 437, 439, 357 S.E.2d
  21, 22 (1987). Â The introduction of a nontestifying co-defendantâ€™s statement
  which implicates a defendant violates a defendantâ€™s right
  to confrontation because no opportunity to cross-examine the co-defendant is
  presented. Bruton v. United States, 391 U.S. 123 (1968). Â Because the right to confrontation is so fundamental,
  limiting instructions are not an adequate substitute. Â Id.; See also State v. Dennis, 337 S.C. 275, 523 S.E.2d 173 (1999) (recognizing that
  in Bruton, the Supreme Court held that a
  defendantâ€™s rights under the Confrontation Clause of the Sixth Amendment are
  violated by the admission of a nontestifying co-defendantâ€™s confession that
  inculpates a defendant, even if a cautionary instruction is given).
Redaction
  has come into play as a tool to allow admission of a co-defendantâ€™s confession
  against the confessor in a joint trial. State v. Holmes, 342 S.C. 113, 119,
  536 S.E.2d 671, 674 (2000). Â The point of redaction is to permit the confession
  to be used against the nontestifying confessor, while avoiding implicating his
  co-defendant.Â  Id. Â The Confrontation Clause is not violated when a
  defendantâ€™s name is redacted but other evidence links the statementâ€™s
  application to the defendant, if a proper limiting
  instruction is given.Â  See Richardson v. Marsh, 481 U.S. 200, 211
  (1987) (holding â€œthe Confrontation Clause is not violated by the admission of a
  nontestifying co-defendantâ€™s confession with a proper limiting instruction
  when, as here, the confession is redacted to eliminate not only the defendantâ€™s
  name, but any reference to his or her existence.â€).
Here, as stated
  above, after Pageâ€™s cross-examination of Detective, the State moved to admit
  McKnightâ€™s unredacted statement on the basis that Page had opened the door to
  this testimony due to his questions on Detectiveâ€™s investigative techniques and
  the sufficiency of evidence linked to Page.Â  It is firmly established that
  otherwise inadmissible evidence may be properly admitted when opposing counsel
  opens the door to that evidence.Â  State v. Young, 364 S.C. 476, 485, 613
  S.E.2d 386, 391 (Ct. App. 2005) cert. granted, Jan. 2007; See also State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 632, 591 S.E.2d 600, 605 (2004) (â€œGiven
  that [defendants] maintained that [the company] did not allow pornographic materials
  or links on the website, it is patent that they opened
  the door to this line of inquiry.â€); State v. White,
  361 S.C. 407, 415-16, 605 S.E.2d 540, 544 (2004) (ruling expert could testify
  that she believed the victim in this case because defendant opened
  the door by cross-examining expert about other cases in
  which she did not believe victim); State v. Dunlap, 353 S.C. 539, 541,
  579 S.E.2d 318, 319 (2003) (holding defense counselâ€™s opening statement â€œopened the door to the introduction
  of evidence rebutting the contention that [defendant] was merely an addictâ€); State
    v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 175, 508 S.E.2d 870, 878 (1998) (â€œ[B]ecause
  appellant opened the door about
  his relationship with his wife, the solicitor was entitled to cross-examine him
  regarding the relationship, even if the responses brought out appellantâ€™s prior
  criminal domestic violence conviction.â€).Â  
In the present
  case, the court found Page attempted to elicit replies from Detective
  indicating the only evidence she had gathered linking Page to the crime were contradictory
  statements and testimony of Williams and Girlfriend, while, in reality, she had
  also used co-defendant McKnightâ€™s statements. Â This, the court determined,
  reflected on Detectiveâ€™s credibility as a witness and on the quality of the
  investigation she undertook that led to Pageâ€™s arrest.Â  As a result, the court
  found Page had opened the door during his cross-examination to the extent that
  Detectiveâ€™s testimony warranted bolstering.Â  Detective was then allowed to
  testify the â€œother guyâ€ identified in McKnightâ€™s statement was Page, and the
  court gave a limiting instruction to the jury that it should not consider the
  evidence against Page, but only as to the credibility of Detective and her
  investigation.Â  
Whether a person
  opens the door to the admission of otherwise inadmissible evidence during the
  course of a trial is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State
    v. Adcock, 194 S.C. 234, 234, 9 S.E.2d 730, 732 (1940).Â  See also Corbett v. Fleetwood Homes of North Carolina, 213 F.3d 630 (Table), 2000
  WL 530325 (C.A.4 (S.C.)) (2000).Â  While we recognize the discretionary
  authority of the trial judge in this area, we believe he erred in finding that
  Pageâ€™s counselâ€™s zealous representation of his client required the admission of
  this inadmissible evidence in order to rehabilitate Detectiveâ€™s investigative
  techniques.Â  Nevertheless, we find any error resulting from the admission of
  the unredacted statement was harmless. Â 
Error is harmless
  where it could not reasonably have affected the trialâ€™s outcome. Â State v.
    Mitchell, 286 S.C. 572, 573, 336 S.E.2d 150, 151 (1985). Â No definite rule of law governs the finding that an error
  was harmless; rather, the materiality and prejudicial character of the error
  must be determined from its relationship to the entire case. Â State v.
    Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 193-94, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990).Â  In
  considering whether error is harmless, a caseâ€™s particular facts must be
  considered along with various factors including:

  ... the importance of the witnessâ€™ testimony in the
    prosecutionâ€™s case, whether the testimony was cumulative, the presence or
    absence of evidence corroborating or contradicting the testimony of the witness
    on material points, the extent of cross-examination otherwise permitted, and,
    of course, the overall strength of the prosecutionâ€™s case.

State v. Clark, 315 S.C. 478,
  481, 445 S.E.2d 634, 635 (1994) (quoting Delaware v. Van Arsdall, 475 U.S. 673, 684 (1986)). Â Thus, an insubstantial error not affecting the result of the trial
  is harmless where â€œguilt has been conclusively proven by competent evidence
  such that no other rational conclusion can be reached.â€ Â State v. Bailey,
  298 S.C. 1, 5, 377 S.E.2d 581, 584 (1989). Â Generally, appellate courts will
  not set aside convictions due to insubstantial errors not affecting the result.
  Â State v. Sherard, 303 S.C. 172, 176, 399 S.E.2d 595, 597 (1991).Â  
Harmless error was
  found in State v. Gillian, where the testimony was â€œlargely cumulativeâ€
  to testimony from other witnesses and other evidence suggested Gillian was
  guilty.Â  State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 456-57, 602 S.E.2d 62, 74-75
  (Ct. App. 2004), affâ€™d as modified on other grounds, 373 S.C. 601, 646
  S.E.2d 872 (2007).Â  In Gillian, we stated that â€œ[n]o definite rule of law
  governs the finding that an error was harmless; rather, the materiality and
  prejudicial character of the error
  must be determined from its relationship to the entire case.â€Â  Id., at 454-55, 602 S.E.2d at 73. 
Applying the Van
  Arsdall factors to the case at hand, we note that all of McKnightâ€™s
  statement mentioning Page was either cumulative or corroborated by other
  witnesses.Â  McKnightâ€™s statement references Page specifically on four
  occasions.Â  The first two occasions, McKnight references the two â€œlittle pocket
  gunsâ€ McCollum and Page were carrying. Â As described above, co-defendant
  Williams had already testified McCollum was carrying â€œa little small .25â€ and
  that â€œit was an automatic.â€Â  Meanwhile, Williams testified that Page carried â€œa
  little .32, old rusty looking .32 . . . revolver.â€Â  
The third occasion
  McKnightâ€™s statement mentions Page, it places him at the apartments, and repeats
  that â€œ[McCollum] and Page kept playing with their guns, pulling them out and
  pointing at us playing.â€Â  In addition to Williamsâ€™ testimony that Page had a
  gun, the testimony or statements of four people placed Page at the apartments.Â 
  These included: Â Nephew, Girlfriend, Williams, and Mary Burress whose statement
  placing McCollum and Page on her porch at the Hall Street Apartments the day of
  Victimâ€™s murder was read into evidence by Detective during her testimony.Â 
  Finally, McKnightâ€™s statement placed Page on Nephewâ€™s porch during the
  commission of the murder.Â  As indicated above, the testimony of both Williams
  and Girlfriend had already placed Page on the porch; therefore McKnightâ€™s
  statement was merely cumulative to the evidence already on the record. Â 
Moreover, prior to the admission of the unredacted statement, Detective was asked to respond to
  a question on cross-examination from Page as to whether she corroborated the
  details of Williamsâ€™ statements to police.Â  Detective testified that â€œ[the
  police] did talk to other people and were unable to corroborate [Williamsâ€™s
  statements] until we corroborated it through Terrance McKnightâ€™s statement.â€
  Â (emphasis added).Â  This testimony was not objected to at the time.Â  A
  contemporaneous objection is required to preserve issues for direct appellate
  review.Â  Webb v. CSX Transp., Inc., 364 S.C. 639, 657, 615 S.E.2d 440,
  450 (2005).Â  As the Supreme Court has stressed on several occasions, the
  Constitution entitles a criminal defendant to a fair trial, not a perfect one. Â See United States v. Hasting, 461 U.S. 499, 508-509 (1983); Bruton,
  391 U.S. 135.Â  Â 

CONCLUSION
As a result of the foregoing, we hold that any error allowing the introduction of Pageâ€™s nontestifying
  co-defendantâ€™s statement implicating Page to the police was harmless beyond a
  reasonable doubt.Â  The decision of the
  circuit court is accordingly
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE, J.,
  and THOMAS, J., concur.


[1] Howard
  was McCollumâ€™s girlfriend and was pregnant with his child at the time of the
  incident; McCollum is a co-defendant in this case.Â  
[2] Williams, as referenced above, was already in
  custody, and gave Detective several statements which led to the other
  defendantsâ€™ arrests.

title: Estate of Nicholson v. South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the Administrative Law Judge's decision to uphold the Department of Health and Human Services' denial of a son's request for an undue hardship waiver under the South Carolina Medicaid program.  The Administrative Law Judge found the son was not "actually residing" with the mother at the time the hardship waiver was requested and, therefore, did not qualify for the waiver.  The Court of Appeals agreed, holding the phrase "actually residing" requires physical presence in the decedent's home at the time the waiver is requested.  Because the son was not living in the mother's home when he applied for the waiver, the waiver was properly denied.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The Estate of Ada B. Nicholson, by Ronald D. Nicholson, Personal Representative, Appellant,
			
		
	

v.

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Health and Human Services, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From The Administrative Law Court
Â Ralph King Anderson, III, Administrative
  Law Judge
Opinion No.Â  4368
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed April 3,
  2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert J. Thomas, Sarah L. Clingman, and Amy M. Lander, of
  Columbia, for Appellant.
				George R. Burnett, South Carolina Department of Health and Human
  Services, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.: Â Ronald D. Nicholson, as the Personal Representative (the PR) for the Estate of
  Ada B. Nicholson (Mother), appeals the decision of the Administrative Law
  Judge (ALJ) affirming the South Carolina Department of Health and Human
  Servicesâ€™ (the Department) denial of Max Nicholsonâ€™s (Son) request for an undue
  hardship waiver under the South Carolina Medicaid program (Medicaid).Â  We affirm.Â 
 
FACTS
In April 1996, Mother began receiving services from Community Long
  Term Care (CLTC), a program provided by Medicaid.Â  CLTC provides services to
  Medicaid recipients who elect to receive assistance in their homes rather than
  seek admission to a nursing facility.Â  Mother continued to receive these
  services until January 1999 when she moved into Easley Nursing Home (the Nursing
  Home). Â While in the Nursing Home, Motherâ€™s care was paid for by Medicaid.Â  In
  July 2004, Mother passed away.Â  Motherâ€™s estate consisted of a partial interest
  in her home.Â  
Following Motherâ€™s death, the Department determined it had paid
  $206,616.26 for CLTC and/or nursing home care on Motherâ€™s behalf, and
  subsequently, the Department filed a claim in that amount against Motherâ€™s
  estate.Â  The PR then requested a hardship waiver on behalf of Son, who was
  incarcerated at the time, claiming Son had lived with Mother for more than two
  years prior to her entering the Nursing Home, which would preclude the
  Department from asserting an interest in Motherâ€™s home.Â  Son had been
  incarcerated since October 2002.Â   
The Department denied the PRâ€™s request.Â  The Department stated the
  hardship waiver would not be granted for the following reasons: (1) Sonâ€™s
  income exceeded 185% of the federal poverty guidelines; (2) Son was not
  actually residing in Motherâ€™s home at the time the waiver was requested; and
  (3) Son had not lived in Motherâ€™s home in over two and a half years prior to
  Motherâ€™s institutionalization.Â  Pursuant to the provisions of the Appeals and
  Hearings regulations of the Department, the PR appealed the Departmentâ€™s
  denial, and a hearing was scheduled.Â   
The Hearing Officer assigned to review the PRâ€™s appeal
  subsequently concurred with the Departmentâ€™s decision to deny the waiver.Â  The
  Hearing Officer additionally found CLTC services were the functional equivalent
  of nursing home care.Â  The PR then appealed the Hearing Officerâ€™s decision to
  the Administrative Law Court.Â  Although the ALJ did not rule on the issue of
  whether CLTC is the functional equivalent of institutionalization, the ALJ did
  find Son was not â€œactually residingâ€ in Motherâ€™s home when the waiver
  application was submitted.Â  The ALJ, therefore, upheld the Hearing Officerâ€™s
  denial of Sonâ€™s hardship waiver.Â  This appeal follows.Â   
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAppeals from decisions by the [D]epartment are heard pursuant to
  the Administrative Procedures Act [(APA)] . . . .â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-6-190
  (2002).Â Â  The APA, therefore, determines the standard of judicial review for
  cases initially heard by the Department. Â Toddâ€™s Ice Cream, Inc. v. S.C.
    Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 281 S.C. 254, 257, 315 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App.
  1984).Â  â€œIt is well settled that in reviewing a decision by an administrative
  agency, this Court will not substitute its judgment for that of the agency
  concerning the weight of the evidence as to questions of fact.â€Â  Kearse v.
    State Health and Human Servs. Fin. Commâ€™n, 318 S.C. 198, 200, 456 S.E.2d
  892, 893 (1995).Â  â€œPursuant to the APA, this [C]ourt may reverse or modify an
  agency decision which is either affected by error of law or clearly erroneous
  in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence in the record.â€ Â S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation v. Girgis, 332 S.C. 162, 166,
  503 S.E.2d 490, 492 (Ct. App. 1998). Â The substantial evidence standard is met
  if a reasonable mind might accept the evidence as adequate to support the
  agencyâ€™s conclusion.Â  Kearse, 318 S.C. at 200, 456 S.E.2d at 893.Â  Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The PR argues the ALJ erred in finding Son was not â€œactually residingâ€
  in Motherâ€™s home when the hardship application was made.Â  We disagree.Â   
The Department may seek recovery of medical assistance paid under
  Medicaid from the estate of an individual who, at the age of fifty-five or
  older, received medical assistance consisting of nursing facility services or
  home and community-based services.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-7-460(A)(2) (Supp.
  2007).Â  The Department must waive recovery, however, upon proof of undue
  hardship asserted by an heir or devisee of the decedent.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  43-7-460(C) (Supp. 2007).Â   
An undue hardship exists if the surviving child of the decedent
  lived in the home of the decedent for at least two years immediately prior to
  the decedentâ€™s institutionalization.Â  Section 43-7-460(C)(1)(d). Â The child
  claiming this hardship, however, must have been â€œactually residing in
  the [decedentâ€™s] home at the time the hardship [was] claimed.â€Â  Section
  43-7-460(C)(1) (emphasis added).Â  Another situation allowing for an undue hardship
  waiver is when the claimant has been living in the decedentâ€™s home two years
  prior to the decedentâ€™s death, owns no real property, and earns below a certain
  income level.Â  Section 43-7-460(C)(2)(a), (c), (d).Â  As in the previous example,
  however, the claimant must have been â€œactually residing in the
  [decedentâ€™s] home at the time the hardship [was] claimed.â€Â  Section
  43-7-460(C)(2)(b) (emphasis added).Â  The statute fails to define the phrase
  â€œactually residing.â€Â  Consequently, we must turn to the rules of statutory
  construction to ascertain the phraseâ€™s meaning.Â  
The
  cardinal rule of statutory construction is to determine and give effect to the
  intent of the legislature.Â  Charleston County Sch. Dist. v.
    State Budget & Control Bd., 313 S.C. 1, 5, 437 S.E.2d 6, 8 (1993).Â  The
  best evidence of legislative intent is the text of the statute. Â Jones v.
    State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 231, 612 S.E.2d 719, 724 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  If â€œthe terms of the statute are clear, the court must apply those
  terms according to their literal meaning.â€Â  City of Columbia v. Am. Civil
    Liberties Union of S.C., Inc., 323 S.C. 384, 387, 475 S.E.2d 747, 749
  (1996).Â  Â Â If there is any ambiguity in the statute, however, that ambiguity
  â€œshould be resolved in favor of a just, equitable, and beneficial operation of
  the law.â€Â  Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 340, 478 S.E.2d
  74, 77 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[t]he language [of the statute] must
  also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords
  with its general purpose.â€Â  Cox v. BellSouth Telecomm., 356 S.C. 468,
  472, 589 S.E.2d 766, 768 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œWhere a word is not defined in a
  statute, our appellate courts have looked to the usual dictionary meaning to
  supply its meaning.â€Â  Lee v. Thermal Engâ€™g Corp., 352 S.C. 81, 91-92,
  572 S.E.2d 298, 303-04 (Ct. App. 2002).Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
â€œResideâ€ has been defined as (1) to dwell permanently or
  continuously; (2) to have a settled abode for a time; or (3) to have oneâ€™s
  residence or domicile.Â  Websterâ€™s Third New International Dictionary 1931
  (1986).Â  However, in the legal field, the term â€œresideâ€ has been defined as to
  â€œ[l]ive, dwell, abide, sojourn, stay, remain, [or] lodge.â€ Blackâ€™s law dictionary 1176 (5th ed. 1979).Â  Additionally, the
  term â€œresidenceâ€ has been defined as â€œ[t]he place where one actually lives, as
  distinguished from a domicile . . . .â€ Â Blackâ€™s law dictionary 1050 (7th ed. 2000).Â  â€œDomicileâ€ has been
  defined as â€œ[t]he place at which a person is physically present and that the
  person regards as home; a personâ€™s true, fixed, principal, and permanent home,
  to which that person intends to return and remain even though currently
  residing elsewhere.â€Â  Id. at 396. Â 
In light of these definitions, â€œresidenceâ€ is a somewhat general
  and fluid term. Â When read alone, the word â€œresidenceâ€ is susceptible to
  varying interpretations.Â  Phillips v. S.C. Tax Commâ€™n, 195 S.C. 472, 476,
  12 S.E.2d 13, 15 (1940).Â  It may have a restricted or enlarged meaning, and
  therefore, the precise meaning of the term is dependent upon the explanatory
  context.Â  Id. at 476-77, 12 S.E.2d at 15-16.
The context in which â€œactually residingâ€ is used in Section
  43-7-460 indicates the phrase has a restricted meaning of physical presence,
  rather than a broader meaning of domicile. Â The statute allows for waivers of
  the Stateâ€™s recovery only in situations when the ramifications would be
  extremely detrimental to the claimant.Â  See Section 43-7-460(C) (stating
  the Department must waive recovery if an heir or devisee proves undue hardship
  will ensue).Â  The requirement that the claimant must actually be living in the
  decedentâ€™s home when the undue hardship waiver is claimed is one way the
  statute ensures the waivers are permitted in only those limited situations.Â  Â Â 
This restricted meaning of physical presence is bolstered by the
  emphasis added by the adverb â€œactually.â€Â  This adverb stresses the importance
  that the claimant must currently be living in the decedentâ€™s home when the
  hardship is claimed.Â  Looking at the language of the statute, it is
  insufficient to show the decedentâ€™s home is the claimantâ€™s domicile without
  proof the home is also the claimantâ€™s current residence.Â  This interpretation
  is in line with previous case law which has recognized that â€œâ€˜residenceâ€™ is a
  more elastic and flexible term than domicile or citizenship.Â  A person may have
  only one domicile, but may have several residences.â€Â  Cook v. Fed. Ins. Co.,
  263 S.C. 575, 582, 211 S.E.2d 881, 884 (1975).Â  We also note, while a personâ€™s
  â€œlegal residenceâ€ is often determined by his or her domicile, a personâ€™s
  â€œactual residenceâ€ will be determined by his or her â€œpresent physical
  location.â€Â  25 Am. Jur. 2d Domicil Â§ 9 (2008).Â  This distinction between actual
  residence and legal residence has long been recognized. See Phillips,
  195 S.C. at 477, 12 S.E.2d at 16 (â€œBut a distinction has long been made between actual residence and legal residence.â€) (emphasis in original).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
Finding the phrase â€œactually residingâ€ requires physical presence
  in the decedentâ€™s home, Son must have been currently living in Motherâ€™s home when
  the hardship waiver application was made. Â Son was incarcerated at the South
  Carolina Department of Corrections when the PR requested the undue hardship
  waiver, and thus, he was not physically present in Motherâ€™s home when the
  hardship waiver application was made.Â  Therefore, Son did not meet the
  requirements for an undue hardship waiver, and the waiver was properly denied.Â  Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the decision of the ALJ is
AFFIRMED.[1]  
HUFF and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
