THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        2003-CP-10-00140
        
          Jamia Hoard, a
            minor under the age of fourteen years, by Karen Elizabeth Hoard, her mother, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Roper Hospital,
          Inc.; Carolina Care Alliance; Karen Johnson; Robert H. Smith, M.D.; Marshall
          Goldstein, M.D.; and John Doe and Mary Roe, representing one or more unknown
          parties, Defendants,
        of whom:
        Robert H.
          Smith, M.D., is the Respondent.
        2003-CP-10-00142
        
        Karen Elizabeth
      Hoard and William Dwight, Appellants,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Roper Hospital,
          Inc.; Carolina Care Alliance; Karen Johnson; Robert H. Smith, M.D.; Marshall
          Goldstein, M.D.; and John Doe and Mary Roe, representing one or more unknown
          parties, Defendants,
        of whom:
        Robert H.
          Smith, M.D., is the Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
  Â J. C. â€œBuddyâ€ Nicholson, Jr., Circuit
  Court Judge

Opinion No. 4377
  Heard March 5, 2008 â€“ Refiled April 24,
2008
Formerly Unpublished Opinion No.
2008-UP-209
Heard March 5, 2008 â€“ Filed March 27, 2008

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Coming B. Gibbs, Jr., Cameron Marshall, and Paul N. Uricchio, all of
          Charleston, for Appellants.
        Andrew F. Lindemann, of Columbia, M. Dawes Cooke, Jr., and P.
          Gunnar Nistad, both of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In
  this medical malpractice action, Jamia Hoard and her parents, Karen Elizabeth Hoard and William
  Dwight (collectively the Hoards), appeal the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary
  judgment to Dr. Robert H. Smith on their cause of action for medical
  malpractice.Â  The Hoards assert they provided evidence Dr. Smith was a
  proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
Jamia was born on March 30, 2002, at Roper Hospital (the Hospital) in Charleston.Â  Shortly thereafter, she developed a
  respiratory condition and was transferred to a level II nursery,[1] where Dr. Marshall Goldstein, a
  neonatologist,[2] was her primary physician.Â  Jamiaâ€™s condition necessitated an
  intravenous line to administer medication and fluids.Â  Because the nursing
  staff was unable to start a peripheral intravenous line, Dr. Goldstein ordered Karen
  Johnson, a certified neonatal nurse practitioner, to place an umbilical
  intravenous line.[3]Â  Johnson placed the line on the afternoon of March 30, 2002.Â  When
  inserted eleven to thirteen centimeters, the optimal location for such a
  catheter, the line would not draw[4] blood. Nurse Johnson then placed the line at fourteen centimeters.Â  Following the
  Hospitalâ€™s protocol, a chest x-ray was taken on March 30 to confirm the position
  of the line. Â 
The next morning, Dr. Smith, a radiologist, reviewed Jamiaâ€™s chest
  x-ray and prepared a report stating, â€œAn umbilical vein catheter has been
  placed.Â  The tip terminates high within the right atrium.Â  There are persistent
  bilateral coarse infiltrates essentially unchanged compared with the prior
  one.Â  No pneumothorax is seen.â€Â  Dr. Smithâ€™s report was approved at
  10:34 a.m. and sent to Jamiaâ€™s floor.Â  At 2 p.m. that afternoon Dr. Goldstein
  reviewed Dr. Smithâ€™s report. Â He did not adjust the placement of the
  line.Â  
At 4:15 a.m. on April 1, Jamia went into cardiac arrest.Â  Jamia
  was transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit[5] of the Medical University of South
  Carolina (MUSC) where it was determined the wall of the right atrium was
  perforated allowing blood and intravenous fluid to fill the pericardial sac
  around the heart, effectively causing tamponade.[6]Â  MUSC physicians ascertained that the umbilical intravenous line most likely
  eroded the wall of the heart a few hours prior to the cardiac arrest, and as a
  result Jamia suffered severe brain damage.Â  
Jamia and her parents separately filed
  professional negligence actions against the Hospital; Carolina Care Alliance,
  the owner and operator of the Hospital; Nurse Johnson; Dr. Smith; and Dr.
  Goldstein.Â  The Hoards asserted Dr. Smith violated his standard of care
  by failing to note in his x-ray report the line was improperly placed and this
  failure was a proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries. Â The Hoards claimed
  Dr. Goldstein may not have known the line was improperly placed and if Dr.
  Smith had alerted him to the placement, Dr. Goldstein would have moved the
  line, and prevented the cardiac arrest.Â  
In his deposition, Dr. Paul Koenigsberg, a radiologist from Florida, testified that Dr. Smith violated the standard of care by failing to note on the
  chart or notify someone the line was improperly placed. Â Dr. Goldstein
  testified he knew the line was not optimally placed but chose not to reposition
  it for several reasons, including the lineâ€™s proven efficacy over twenty-two
  hours and the possibility of moving a blood clot that may have formed at the
  tip of the line. Â Dr. Anne Hansen, an assistant professor at Harvard University Medical School, described Dr. Goldsteinâ€™s reasons for not moving the
  line as a non-valid concern. 
The Hoards settled their claims with the Hospital, Carolina Care
  Alliance, Nurse Johnson, and Dr. Goldstein. Â Dr. Smith made a motion for
  summary judgment.Â  The trial court granted the motion, finding the Hoards did
  not provide evidence Dr. Smith was a proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries.Â  The
  Hoardsâ€™ motion for amendment of judgment was denied. Â This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary
  judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial
  court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no
  genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to
  judgment as a matter of law.  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493,
  567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).  In determining whether a triable issue of
  fact exists, the evidence and all factual inferences drawn from it must be
  viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.  Sauner v.
    Pub. Serv. Auth., 354 S.C. 397, 404, 581 S.E.2d 161, 165 (2003).  If evidentiary
  facts are not disputed but the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them
  are, summary judgment should be denied. Baugus v. Wessinger, 303 S.C.
  412, 415, 401 S.E.2d 169, 171 (1991).  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  Hoards contend the trial court erred in granting Dr. Smithâ€™s motion for summary
  judgment because they provided evidence Dr. Smith was a proximate cause of
  Jamiaâ€™s injuries.Â  The Hoards assert a jury could have disregarded Dr.
  Goldsteinâ€™s testimony and found Dr. Smithâ€™s failure to alert Dr. Goldstein of
  the lineâ€™s position was a proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries.Â  We agree.
â€œMedical
  malpractice lawsuits have specific requirements that must be satisfied in order
  for a genuine factual issue to exist.â€Â David v. McLeod Regâ€™l
    Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  Specifically, a
  plaintiff alleging medical malpractice must provide evidence showing: (1) the
  generally recognized and accepted practices and procedures that would be
  followed by average, competent practitioners in the defendantâ€™s field of
  medicine under the same or similar circumstances, and (2) the defendant
  departed from the recognized and generally accepted standards.Â  Jones v. Doe,
  372 S.C. 53, 61, 640 S.E.2d 514, 518 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Additionally, the plaintiff must demonstrate the defendantâ€™s
  departure from such generally recognized practices and procedures proximately
  caused the plaintiffâ€™s alleged injuries and damages. Â David, 367 S.C. at
  248, 626 S.E.2d at 4.Â  
If
  the subject matter does not lie within common knowledge but requires special
  learning to evaluate the conduct of the defendant, then the plaintiff must offer
  expert testimony to establish both the required standard of care and the
  defendantâ€™s failure to conform to that standard. Id.Â  Because â€œmany
  malpractice suits involve ailments and treatments outside the realm of ordinary
  lay knowledge, expert testimony is generally necessary.â€Â  Ellis v. Oliver,
  323 S.C. 121, 125, 473 S.E.2d 793, 795 (1996). When plaintiffs rely
  solely upon medical expert testimony as the only evidence of proximate cause,
  the medical expert must, with reasonable certainty, state it is their opinion the
  injuries complained of most probably resulted from the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  Id.Â  The testimony â€œmust provide a significant causal link between the
  alleged negligence and the plaintiffâ€™s injuries, rather than a tenuous and
  hypothetical connection.â€ Â Id.
For
  this court to reverse grants of summary judgment, plaintiffs must have provided
  some evidence for each element of their claims.Â  In the present case, the
  Hoards must have presented evidence Dr. Smith violated the standard of care and
  that violation was a proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries.Â  
1.Â The Hoards presented
  evidence regarding a radiologistâ€™s standard of care and violations of that
  standard.Â  Dr. Koenigsberg testified radiologists have a duty and standard of
  care to immediately convey urgent information to the person who ordered the
  film.Â  He also testified it would be outside a radiologistâ€™s standard of care
  to not directly communicate to the treating physician or his nurses that an
  umbilical venous line was not properly positioned. Â Another radiologist
  from Florida, Dr. Rodan, testified that when a radiologist sees a line high in
  the right atrium, to be within the standard of care, he should state his
  impression there is a deviation from the normal placement of a line. Â Dr.
  Rodan further stated â€œif there is a malposition it needs to be stated in such
  language that the referring physician knows that itâ€™s in an inappropriate
  location and that they should consider doing something such as repositioning
  the catheter.â€Â  
Accordingly,
  the Hoards provided evidence to support their assertion Dr. Smith violated the
  standard of care, and we turn our examination to whether there is evidence Dr.
  Smith was a proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries.
2.Â The Hoards claim Dr.
  Smithâ€™s failure to alert Dr. Goldstein to the position of the line was a
  proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries.Â  Dr. Smith
  asserts the Hoards did not provide any evidence of proximate cause because Dr. Goldstein
  testified he knew the line was not optimally positioned. However, a jury could
  have chosen not to believe Dr. Goldsteinâ€™s testimony. Simply because testimony
  is uncontradicted does not render it undisputed. Â Black v. Hodge, 306 S.C. 196, 198, 410 S.E.2d 595, 596 (Ct. App.
  1991).Â  The question of the inherent probability of the testimony and the
  credibility of the witness remains. Id.Â  Even when evidence is not contradicted,
  the jury may believe all, some, or none of the testimony and the matter is
  properly left to the jury to decide.Â  Ross v. Paddy, 340 S.C. 428, 434, 532 S.E.2d 612, 615 (Ct. App.
  2000).Â  
When
  asked if Dr. Smithâ€™s alleged failure to communicate orally with Dr. Goldstein
  in any way caused the cardiac arrest, Dr. Koenigsberg explained if there was a
  delay between the placement of the line and the time at which the treating
  physicians realized the line was in an abnormal position, that could have
  caused the pericardial effusion. Â Dr. Koenigsberg also stated he believed Dr.
  Smith was negligent for failing to call someone responsible for Jamiaâ€™s care
  and inform them the tip of the catheter was in an abnormal position. Â Dr.
  Koenigsberg testified if Dr. Goldstein knew of the lineâ€™s placement prior to
  the line perforating the wall of the heart and had the opportunity to pull the
  line back before injury occurred, Dr. Smith did not cause the pericardial
  effusion.[7] Â However, Dr. Koenigsberg also responded affirmatively when asked, â€œIs
  it your opinion that Dr. Smithâ€™s alleged failure to orally communicate with
  Jamia Hoardâ€™s health care personnel, caused her to have a pericardial
  effusion?â€ 
In
  addition, Dr. Rodan testified, â€œI think the lack of completeness of [Dr.
  Smithâ€™s] report did contribute to the complications that occurred to the
  patient.â€ Â Assuming Dr. Goldstein did not know the location of the
  catheterâ€™s tip was outside the standard of care, Dr. Rodan testified Dr.
  Smithâ€™s failure to point out the deviation from the standard of care was â€œa
  contributing cause to the complications that occurred.â€ Â Dr. Rodan believed
  â€œsome of the complications thatâ€¦ occurred may be a direct responsibility of the
  radiologist because of his inadequate report.â€ 
An
  examination of the record shows the Hoards provided evidence supporting their
  assertion Dr. Smith was a proximate cause of Jamiaâ€™s injuries.Â  Accordingly,
  the order of the trial court is 
REVERSED.
ANDERSON and SHORT, and THOMAS, JJ., concur.


[1] Nurseries can be
  distinguished based on the needs of an infant and the abilities of a facility.Â 
  Level II nurseries provide care for infants who need more help or closer
  monitoring than a Level I nursery can provide.Â  Infants in Level II nurseries
  may need intravenous fluids or medications, assistance to maintain their body
  temperature, feeding assistance, or monitoring for sleep apnea.Â  Level III
  nurseries or newborn intensive care units (NICUs) provide even greater care to
  infants, including subspecialty services, the use of ventilators, close
  observation of infants whose condition is unstable, and care following surgery.
[2] Neonatology is a subspecialty of pediatric medicine,
  concerning the care and treatment of newborns.Â  
[3] An umbilical
  intravenous line is a catheter that is placed in the vein of the umbilical
  cord. 
[4] A catheter â€œdrawsâ€ when you exert negative pressure on the
  catheter and blood flows out of the body through the catheter.Â  
[5] MUSCâ€™s neonatal intensive care unit is the regionâ€™s
  Level III care facility.
[6] Tamponade is the restriction of heart function by
  fluid in the pericardial sac.Â  
[7] Pericardial effusion is an accumulation of fluid in
  the pericardial sac.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Amy Bailey
      Thomson, Respondent,
				v.
				Colin Andrew
      Thomson, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Gerald C. Smoak, Jr., Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4378
Submitted March 3, 2008 â€“ Filed April 25,
2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				J. Benjamin Stevens, of Spartanburg, and John S. Nichols, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Richard H. Rhodes, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:  Colin Thomson (Husband) appeals from the final order of the family
  court granting Amy Thomson (Wife) a divorce on the ground of physical cruelty
  and ordering him to pay: (1) $99 per week in child support; (2) one-half of
  accumulated marital debt; (3) thirty-six percent of the childrenâ€™s future
  uninsured medical bills; and (4) $5,000 toward Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Husband
  also appeals the courtâ€™s declaration that Wife owned all the property in her
possession.Â  We affirm.[1] 

FACTS

In February 2004, Husband and Wife met on a dating website.Â  Wife held
  a masterâ€™s degree and worked as a college swim coach and teacher. Â She owned a furnished
  home in Spartanburg, South Carolina.Â  Husband, a Canadian citizen, worked in
  furniture sales.Â  Prior to their marriage, Wife agreed to sponsor Husbandâ€™s
  application for a visa.Â  After their August 2004 marriage, Husband moved into Wifeâ€™s
  home. Â Wife worked two jobs; however, Husband delayed submitting his visa application until February 2005 and,
  consequently, remained unemployed
  until May 2005.Â  
Shortly after their marriage, Wife became pregnant. Â Her pregnancy
  was considered â€œhigh-riskâ€ because she was thirty-seven years old and expecting
  twins. Â The children were born six weeks prematurely and remained in the
  newborn intensive care unit for twelve days.Â  After Wife returned to work, wifeâ€™s
  mother Carrie Bailey, who had moved from Michigan to the home to help care for
  the children, remained in the home to provide child-care.Â  
On August 18, 2005, Wife filed a complaint seeking: (1) a divorce
  on the ground of physical cruelty; (2) sole custody of the children; (3) equitable
  division of marital debt; (4) child support; and (5) attorneysâ€™ fees. Â While Wife
  and the children were attending a function at Wifeâ€™s school, Husband vacated
  the home and removed numerous items of Wifeâ€™s personal property.Â  Based upon Wifeâ€™s
  motion for emergency relief, wherein she claimed Husband had become â€œvolatile
  and irrational,â€ the family court issued an ex parte order that mutually restrained
  Husband and Wife from interaction, temporarily restrained Husband from contact
  with the children, and granted Wife temporary custody. Â 
At a subsequent hearing, the family court, finding Husband was not
  an immediate threat to the children or a flight risk, granted him unsupervised
  visitation. Â Further, the family court ordered Husband to pay child support of
  $133 per week, to return the personal property he removed from Wifeâ€™s home, and
  it imposed a mutual restraining order. Â 
Ultimately, the family court issued a final order granting Wife a
  divorce on the ground of physical cruelty, sole custody of the children, and $5,000
  toward her attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Husband was awarded visitation within the United States, and was ordered to pay child support of $99 a week, in addition to thirty-six
  percent of the childrenâ€™s future medical bills that were not covered by insurance.
  Â The court also ordered Husband and Wife to divide their accumulated marital
  debt and the childrenâ€™s unpaid medical bills. Â Additionally, the court declared
  Wife owned all of the property in her possession as well as the property the
  court had previously ordered Husband return to her. Â Husbandâ€™s appeal
  followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A
  divorce action is a matter in equity heard by the family court judge; on
  appeal, the courtâ€™s scope of review extends to the finding of facts based on
  its own view of the preponderance of the
  evidence.Â  McLaughlin v. McLaughlin, 283 S.C. 404, 405-06, 323 S.E.2d
  781, 782 (1984). Â However, our broad scope of review does not require us to
  disregard the findings of the family court or to ignore the fact that the trial
  judge saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate
  their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony. Â Tinsley
    v. Tinsley, 326 S.C. 374, 380, 483 S.E.2d 198, 201 (Ct. App. 1997). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
A.  Physical Cruelty 
Husband contends the family court erred in granting Wife a divorce
  on the ground of physical cruelty.Â  We disagree. Â 
Physical
  cruelty is â€œactual personal violence, or such a course of physical treatment as
  endangers life, limb or health, and renders cohabitation unsafe.â€ Â Brown v.
    Brown, 215 S.C. 502, 508, 56 S.E.2d 330, 333 (1949).Â  In considering what
  acts constitute physical cruelty, the court must consider the circumstances of
  the particular case.Â  Gibson v. Gibson, 283 S.C. 318, 322, 322 S.E.2d
  680, 682 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
In Gibson,
  the husband appealed a family court order denying him a divorce on the ground
  of physical cruelty after his intoxicated wife allegedly locked herself in the bedroom
  and shot a rifle into the closed door.Â  The husband claimed a splinter from the
  door struck him in the face; however, his wife claimed he was in a different
  room when she fired the gun. Â Id. at 322, 322 S.E.2d at 682.Â  The family
  court held that because the husband was not physically injured, the wifeâ€™s
  conduct did not constitute physical cruelty.Â  Id. at 322, 322 S.E.2d at
  683.Â  
Prior
  to Gibson, no South Carolina case directly addressed whether it was
  necessary for a spouse to prove bodily injury when seeking a divorce on the
  ground of physical cruelty.Â  Id. at 323, 322 S.E.2d at 683. Â On appeal, the Gibson court conducted an extensive review of the applicable case law
  and held: 

	[I]f
  the wrongful act involves actual violence directed by one spouse at the other, â€œbodily
  injuryâ€ is not required in order to find â€œphysical cruelty.â€
  Â A single assault by one spouse upon the other spouse,
  then, can constitute a basis for a divorce on the ground of physical cruelty;
  however, the assault must be life threatening or it must be either indicative
  of an intention to do serious bodily harm or of such a degree as to raise a
  reasonable apprehension of great bodily harm in the future.Â  

Id. at 323, 322 S.E.2d at 683 (emphasis in original). 
The Gibson court found that although the wife committed a single act of â€œactual violenceâ€
  by firing the rifle, it was unclear whether her act was one of â€œactual personal violenceâ€ directed against Husband.Â  Id. at 323-24, 322 S.E.2d at 683. Â The Gibson court remanded the case to the family court for findings
  regarding the credibility of the parties and the circumstances surrounding the
  wifeâ€™s firing the gun.Â  Id. at 324, 322 S.E.2d at 683-684.Â  See Lucas
    v. Lucas, 279 S.C. 121, 302 S.E.2d 863 (1983) (finding it difficult to fathom
  the reason the family court did not grant wife a divorce on the grounds of
  physical cruelty, but finding no abuse of discretion in the courtâ€™s decision to
  grant the divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s separation); see also McDowell v. McDowell, 300 S.C. 96, 99-100, 386 S.E.2d 468, 470 (Ct. App.
  1989) (affirming the family courtâ€™s grant of a divorce to a husband on the
  ground of physical cruelty where the court found his wifeâ€™s single act of
  â€œaccidentallyâ€ shooting him was life threatening, indicative of her intention
  to do serious bodily harm, and totally out of proportion to his attempt to
  recover a vehicle from her).Â  
Here, Wife testified Husband first physically abused her in
  February 2005, when she was pregnant with twins. Â Wife stated she and Husband
  argued over their finances, and she had gone into the bedroom to calm down when
  â€œhe came in there and I mean basically pulled me off the bed three times by my
  legs.â€Â  Husband, meanwhile, testified Wife kicked him as he tried to retrieve
  bills from under the bed, and he admitted he responded by pulling her off the
  bed by her legs.Â  After this altercation, Husband and Wife separated briefly; however,
  Wife said Husband returned a week later, â€œagainst [her] wishes.â€Â  
Wife also testified Husband â€œroughed her upâ€ on her wrist and
  breast and shattered a glass picture on her stomach; however, the record does
  not indicate when these alleged acts of physical violence occurred. Â Husband admitted
  â€œ[t]here was an incredible amount of physical violence in the houseâ€ and contended
  Wife physically abused him by throwing juice at him and punching him in the
  stomach.Â  Wife admitted throwing juice at Husband after he told her he never
  wanted to marry her, but she denied ever hitting him.Â  
Where
  issues relate to proof regarding which party, if either, is entitled to a
  divorce, and the evidence is in conflict and susceptible to different
  inferences, â€œit becomes the duty of the trial judge to determine not only the
  law of the case but the facts as wellâ€ because the judge observed the witnesses
  and could â€œattach[] to each oneâ€™s testimony such credence as was due.â€Â  Anders
    v. Anders, 285 S.C. 512, 514, 331 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985).Â  Here, the family
  courtâ€™s final order noted its â€œparticular attention to the demeanor of the party
  [testifying] and the substance of that testimonyâ€ and stated concerns regarding
  the credibility of Husbandâ€™s testimony and the testimony of Husbandâ€™s only
  witness, his brother. Â By contrast, the courtâ€™s order did not express concerns
  regarding Wifeâ€™s credibility. Â 
Given
  Wifeâ€™s condition at the time of the alleged act of physical violence, Husbandâ€™s
  acknowledgement that there was a great deal of physical violence in the home,
  and the fact that the family court judge had the opportunity to observe the demeanor
  of the parties, we find sufficient evidence in the record to support the family
  courtâ€™s decision to grant Wife a divorce on the ground of physical cruelty. Â 
B.  Condonation
Husband claims that even if his acts rose to the level
  of physical cruelty, the evidence shows Wife condoned his misconduct when she
  allowed him to move back into the marital residence.Â  We disagree.
â€œOrdinarily condonation is an affirmative defense that must be pleaded.â€Â  McLaughlin v. McLaughlin,
  244 S.C. 265, 272, 136 S.E.2d 537, 540 (1964).Â  However, the issue of
  condonation in a divorce proceeding may be raised for the first time on appeal.Â  Id.Â  But see Doe v. Doe, 286 S.C. 507, 511, 334
  S.E.2d 829, 832 (Ct. App. 1985) (suggesting McLaughlin â€œmay have been
  superseded by the subsequent adoption of Family Court Rule 11 which expressly
  provides that â€˜recrimination and condonation shall be pleaded as affirmative defenses.â€™â€); Rule 8(c), SCRCP (stating when
  pleading to a preceding pleading, a party must set forth the affirmative
  defense of condonation).Â  
Here,
  Husband raises the affirmative defense of condonation for the first time on
  appeal. Â He acknowledges the family courtâ€™s order does not address condonation,
  yet he asks this court to examine the record and find condonation.Â  We decline
  to do so because this issue was neither pled nor raised to the family court
judge.

C.  Child
  Support 
Husband asserts the family court abused its discretion in ordering
  him to pay child support of $99 per week.Â  Specifically, Husband contends the family
  court made no findings to support this award.Â  We disagree.Â  
When
  an order from the family court fails to make specific findings of fact in
  support of the courtâ€™s decision, the appellate court may remand the matter to
  the family court or, â€œwhere the record is sufficient, make its own findings of
  fact in accordance with the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Badeaux v.
    Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 203, 522 S.E.2d 835, 839 (Ct. App. 1999). Â Additionally,
  the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines (Guidelines) allow a court to
  impute potential gross income to a parent who is unemployed or underemployed.Â  See 27 S.C. Code Ann. Regs. Â§ 114-4720 (Supp. 2007).Â  
While
  the family courtâ€™s written order minimally complies with Rule 26(a), SCRCP, the
  record is sufficient for this court to make findings on this issue which
  support the family court order.[2] Â Husband testified he received
  a letter from the Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) in November 2005,
  stating that because Wife had withdrawn her sponsorship of his visa application,
  he was no longer eligible to work in the United States, and must leave the
  country by April 22, 2006.Â  The courtâ€™s
  order found Husband planned to return to Halifax, where he had a job offer
  paying $13 per hour to work forty hours per week.Â  Wife submitted a financial
  declaration showing gross monthly income of $3,916 and a monthly expense of
  $153 for the childrenâ€™s health insurance. Â Although the family courtâ€™s order
  did not state that it had imputed income to Husband based on his testimony, or had
  applied the Guidelines, we find the record contained the facts needed for the
court to compute Husbandâ€™s child support obligation pursuant to the Guidelines.
Based on the
  record before us, we project monthly wages of $2,080 to Husband.Â  Accordingly, the
  family court did not abuse its discretion by ordering Husband to pay $99 per
week in child support.Â  
D.  Equitable
  Division of Marital Debt
Husband argues the family court erred in finding marital debt of $36,560
  and ordering Husband to pay one-half ($18,280) to Wife at a rate of $300 per
  month.Â  Specifically, Husband argues Wife did not sufficiently document that the
  debt incurred during the marriage was related to expenses in support of the
  marriage.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œFor
  purposes of equitable distribution, â€˜marital debtâ€™ is debt incurred for the
  joint benefit of the parties regardless of whether the parties are legally jointly liable for the debt or whether one party is legally
  individually liable.â€Â  Hardy
    v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 436-37, 429 S.E.2d 811, 813 (Ct. App. 1993) (emphasis
  in original). Â The same rules of fairness and equity that apply to the
  equitable distribution of marital property also apply to the equitable division of marital
  debts.Â  Id. at 437, 429 S.E.2d at 814. Â â€œ[T]he
  burden of proving a spouseâ€™s debt as nonmarital rests upon that party who makes
  such [an] assertion.â€Â  Id. at 437, 429 S.E.2d at 814. Â It is a â€œrebuttable
  presumption that a debt of either spouse incurred prior to the beginning of
  marital litigation is a marital debt and must be factored
  in the totality of equitable apportionment.â€Â Wooten
    v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 546, 615 S.E.2d 98, 105 (2005).Â  
Wife testified she expected Husband to be unemployed during the
  ninety-day visa application process, and she had accepted a second job coaching
  three evenings a week to get them through this period.Â  Husband testified he
  sold his assets before he left Canada and arrived in the United States with only a leased car, personal effects, and between $2,000 and $6,000.Â  Husband
agreed he was totally dependent on Wife during that time.Â  
Husband did not begin working until May 2005, nine months after
  their marriage.Â  Wife testified Husband
  did not contribute financially to their marriage, even after he began earning approximately $1,800 a month working at
  Ashley Furniture.Â  She testified
  his only financial contribution to their marriage was $150.[3]Â  Husband did not dispute Wifeâ€™s trial
  testimony and agreed he had not paid any medical bills or contacted the childrenâ€™s
  health care providers to negotiate a payment plan. Â Additionally, Husband did
  not contradict Wifeâ€™s testimony that she made monthly payments on Husbandâ€™s
  outstanding Canadian debts, paid Husbandâ€™s INS application fee of $1,000, paid
  his speeding tickets, and gave him money to open a checking account.Â  Husband stated
  they dined frequently at restaurants, took short vacations together, and purchased
  nursery furniture.Â  Husband also testified he â€œspent many nights in motels just
trying to get away . . . .â€Â  
Wife presented documentation showing her credit card debt had
  increased from $4,500 at the time she married Husband to $36,560 when they separated
  a year later.Â  Wife testified her savings of $8,500 were depleted by paying
  bills related to their household expenses.Â  Wife additionally testified they
  borrowed $4,500 from her mother and $5,460 from her aunt to pay their bills. Â Husband
  testified he was aware of these loans.Â  At trial, Wife presented a summary
  showing $36,560 in marital debt, exclusive of unpaid medical bills.Â  Wife
  introduced this summary into evidence without objection.Â  Husband did not
  challenge Wifeâ€™s statement of marital debt at trial.
Accordingly, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion
  in adopting Wifeâ€™s summary of $36,560 in marital debt, and ordering Husband and
  Wife to evenly divide the debt with Husband paying $300 per month to Wife until
  his $18,280 obligation is satisfied.Â  See Honea v. Honea,
  292 S.C. 456, 458, 357 S.E.2d 191, 192 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œThe trial courtâ€™s
  findings come to us with a presumption of correctness.Â  The burden is on [Appellant]
  to demonstrate the family court committed reversible error.Â  . . . Â [A] party
  cannot sit back at trial without offering proof, then come to this Court
  complaining of the insufficiency of the evidence to support the family courtâ€™s
  findings.â€). Â 
E.  Equitable
  Division of the Marital Estate 
Husband argues the family court failed to properly apportion the
  marital estate.Â  We disagree. 
Section 20-7-473 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007)
  defines marital property as â€œall real and personal property which has been
  acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date
  of filing or commencement of marital litigation.â€Â  However, the statute specifically
  excludes from marital property, â€œproperty acquired by either party before the
  marriage,â€ and states â€œ[t]he court
  does not have jurisdiction or authority to apportion nonmarital
  property.â€ Â Id.
â€œFamily
  court judges have wide discretion in determining how marital property is to be distributed. Â They may use any
  reasonable means to divide the property equitably, and
  their judgment will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Murphy
    v. Murphy, 319 S.C. 324, 329, 461 S.E.2d 39, 41-42 (1995). Â Property
  which is nonmarital at the time of its acquisition may be transmuted into
  marital property â€œ(1) if it becomes so commingled with marital property as to
  be untraceable; (2) if it is titled jointly; or (3) if it is utilized by the
  parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an
  intent by the parties to make it marital property.â€ Â Johnson v. Johnson,
  296 S.C. 289, 295, 372 S.E.2d 107, 110 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  
Wife testified she owned her Spartanburg home and its furnishings
  prior to her marriage.Â  She testified no marital property was acquired during
  the marriage.Â  Husband did not challenge Wifeâ€™s
  testimony.Â  The record contains no facts to support transmutation
  of Wifeâ€™s separate property into marital property.Â  Moreover, Husband did not
  offer evidence showing any marital property was acquired.Â  Accordingly, the
  family court did not abuse its discretion in declaring the property in Wifeâ€™s
  possession, including the home she purchased prior to her marriage, to be nonmarital
  property. 
F.  Childrenâ€™s
  Future Medical Bills 
Husband
  contends the family court erred in ordering him to pay thirty-six percent of the
  childrenâ€™s future medical bills that are not covered by health insurance.Â  While
  Husband does not dispute the courtâ€™s authority to determine a parentâ€™s
  contribution towards medical costs, he contends â€œthe figure of 36% appears from
  thin air.â€Â  We disagree.
As stated above, based upon testimony concerning his prospective
  employment in Canada, we projected monthly gross income to him of $2,080.Â  Wifeâ€™s
  gross monthly income is $3,916, from which $153 a month is deducted for the
  childrenâ€™s health insurance.Â  As a result, Husbandâ€™s imputed income of $2,080 comprises
  thirty-six percent of the $5,843 total monthly gross income available to
  Husband and Wife.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court properly determined
  Husbandâ€™s share of the childrenâ€™s future uninsured medical bills.Â  
G.  Attorneysâ€™
  Fees. 
Husband
  contends the family court erred in ordering Husband to pay $5,000 towards
  Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  We disagree.Â  
An
  award of attorneysâ€™ fees will not be overturned absent an abuse of discretion. Â Stevenson
    v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 415, 368 S.E.2d 901, 903 (1988). Â â€œIn deciding
  whether to award attorneysâ€™ fees, the family court should consider the partiesâ€™
  ability to pay their own fee, the beneficial results obtained by counsel, the
  respective financial conditions of the parties, and the effect of the fee on
  each partyâ€™s standard of living.â€ Â Arnal v. Arnal, 363 S.C. 268, 290,
  609 S.E.2d 821, 833 (Ct. App. 2005), affâ€™d as modified, 371 S.C. 10, 636
  S.E.2d 864 (2006).Â  When the family court finds an award of attorneysâ€™ fees is

  nature, extent, and difficulty of the case; (2) the time necessarily devoted to
  the case; (3) counselâ€™s professional standing; (4) the contingency of

  fees for similar services.Â  Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161,

Wifeâ€™s attorney submitted a fee affidavit documenting

  in the courtâ€™s decision to order Husband to pay $5,000 toward Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™

AFFIRMED.

and THOMAS, JJ., concur.

Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Husbandâ€™s testimony revealed the financial

description: Thomas Bradford appeals the trial courtâ€™s finding he breached a real estate contract with the Madrens. THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Clyde and Nancy Madren, Respondents,
				v.
				Thomas H.
      Bradford, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Dorchester County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge
Opinion No. 4379
Heard March 5, 2008 â€“ Filed April 28, 2008 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				John S. Nichols, of Columbia, W. ScottÂ  Palmer, of Santee, for Appellant.
				Max G. Mahaffee, of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	

THOMAS, J.: Thomas
  Bradford appeals the trial courtâ€™s finding he breached a real estate contract
  with Clyde and Nancy Madren and the resulting award of $55,000.Â  Bradford also
  appeals the trial courtâ€™s finding that Clyde Madren is not barred from bringing
  suit under South Carolina licensing statutes.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS

In
  2002, Clyde and Nancy Madren purchased a tract of land in St. George for
  $82,000.Â  The Madrens divided the tract into three parcels with houses on two
  of the parcels while the third parcel was a vacant lot.Â  A house at 703 Raysor Street was situated on one of the three parcels.Â  The Madrens were remodeling the
  Raysor Street house (House) in August 2002 when Thomas and Miriam Bradford
  approached them about purchasing the House.Â  
The Madrens and Bradfords entered into a Buy and Sell Residential
  Real Estate Contract (Contract) on August 31, 2002. Â The Contract specified
  October 15, 2002, as the closing date. Â The
  Contract was subject to the Bradfords obtaining $120,000 in financing. Â Â In order
  for the Bradfords to secure the necessary financing, the bank required a home appraisal.Â  The Bradfords believed the Madrens would complete several
  home renovations before a closing could take place.Â  Thomas Bradford and Nancy Madren
  communicated numerous times through phone calls and emails regarding renovations, when appraisers could look at the House, and when the closing could
  occur. Â Such communications continued past the Contractâ€™s October 15 closing
  date.Â  
On
  October 31, 2002, the Madrens notified the Bradfords renovations were complete
  and the House was ready for a â€œwalk-through.â€Â  Five days later Thomas Bradford
  responded with an e-mail stating he and his wife no longer intended to purchase
  the House.Â  According to Thomas Bradford, they chose not to purchase the House
  because they did not want to extend the closing date any further. 
On December 31,
  2002, the Madrens brought an action for breach of contract and specific
  performance[1] against the Bradfords.Â  Bradford[2] moved to dismiss the Madrensâ€™ claim on the grounds that Clyde Madren did not
  have a contractorâ€™s license. Â The trial court denied the motion to dismiss. Â The
  trial court found the parties had entered into a binding contract in which time
  was not of the essence.Â  Due to his emails, the trial court found Thomas
  Bradford waived compliance with the Contractâ€™s closing date. Â In addition to finding the Bradfords breached the
  Contract, the trial court further held
  the Bradfords could not defend their breach based on the partiesâ€™ failure to meet the agreed closing date.Â  The trial court awarded the Madrens
  $55,000 in damages.Â  Bradford appealed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On
  appeal of a case tried without a jury, the appellate courtâ€™s jurisdiction is
  limited to correction of errors at law.Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home v. Beasley,
  365 S.C. 157, 164, 616 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2005).Â  The judgeâ€™s findings are
  equivalent to a juryâ€™s findings in a law action.Â  King v. PYA/Monarch, Inc.,
  317 S.C. 385, 389, 453 S.E.2d 885, 888 (1995).Â  Questions regarding credibility
  and weight of evidence are exclusively for the trial judge.Â  Sheek v.
    Crimestoppers Alarm Sys., 297 S.C. 375, 377, 377 S.E.2d 132, 133 (Ct. App.
  1989). The appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact
  as long as they are reasonably supported by the evidence.Â  Epworth, 365
  S.C. at 164, 616 S.E.2d at 714.
LAW / ANALYSIS
I.Â  Contractorâ€™s License
Bradford argues the trial court erred in denying his motion to
  dismiss based on Section 40-11-30 of the South Carolina Code (2006).Â 
  Specifically, Bradford argues the Contract should not be enforced because Clyde
  Madren, in his sole proprietorship, did not possess a contractorâ€™s license.Â  We
  find this affirmative defense was not appropriately pled.
Approximately
  one month before the trial commenced, Bradford filed[3] a motion to dismiss arguing Clyde Madren did not possess a contractorâ€™s license
  as required by South Carolina Code Section 40-11-30, et seq. (1976).Â  Bradford
  further argued the Madrensâ€™ action was barred under South Carolina licensing
  statutes that state, â€œ[a]n entity which does not have a valid license as
  required by this chapter may not bring an action either at law or in equity to
  enforce the provisions of a contract.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-11-370 (1976).Â  Bradford had filed his answer and counterclaim a year and nine months prior with no mention
  of any licensing statute.Â  Bradford did not file an amended answer asserting any
  affirmative defenses in the interim.Â  At the beginning of the trial, the trial
  court denied Bradfordâ€™s motion to dismiss based on the lack of a contractorâ€™s
  license.Â  A post-trial Rule 59(e) motion to reconsider was also denied. 
A
  party, in replying to a preceding pleading, shall affirmatively set forth his
  defenses to the opposing partyâ€™s complaint. Rule 8(c),
    SCRCP. â€œEvery defense, in law or fact, to a cause of action in any
  pleadingâ€¦ shall be asserted in the responsive pleading thereto....â€ Rule 12(b),
    SCRCP.Â  Generally, affirmative defenses to a cause of action in any pleading
  must be asserted in a partyâ€™s responsive pleading. Strickland
    v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 85, 650 S.E.2d 465, 470 (2007) (citing Wright v. Craft, 372 S.C. 1, 20-21, 640 S.E.2d 486, 497 (Ct. App. 2006)).Â 
  Statutory prohibition is in the nature of an affirmative defense precluding
  enforcement of a contract and should be pled.Â  Costa and Sons Const. Co. v.
    Long, 306 S.C. 465, 469, 412 S.E.2d 450, 453 (Ct. App. 1991) (citing Rule
  8(c), SCRCP).
â€œThe
  failure to plead an affirmative defense is deemed a waiver of the right to
  assert it.â€Â  Whitehead v. State, 352 S.C. 215, 220, 574 S.E.2d 200, 202
  (2002).Â  Rule 15(b), SCRCP, provides an exception to the waiver rule by
  permitting a party to amend his pleadings to conform to the evidence. Â No such
  motion was ever made by Bradford.Â  We find Bradford should not be able to argue
  for a potential benefit from an affirmative defense without his being required
  to affirmatively plead it.Â  See Parrish v. Allison, Op. No. 4322
  (S.C. Ct. App. Filed Dec. 19, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 43 at 58), 656 S.E.2d
  382 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  We affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion on this
  basis.[4]
II.Â  Extension of Closing
  Date
Bradford
  next contends the trial court erred in ruling that by his action, conduct, and
  written word, Bradford agreed to extend the closing date beyond October 28,
  2003.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œA
  written contract may be modified by the parties thereto in any manner they
  choose, notwithstanding, agreement prohibiting its alteration except in a
  particular manner.â€Â  Evatt v. Campbell, 234 S.C. 1, 6-7, 106 S.E.2d 447,
  450 (1959).Â  Additionally:Â  

	It is
  well established in this state that time is not of the essence of a contract to
  convey land unless made so by its terms expressly or by implication. When the
  contract does not include a provision that â€œtime is of the essence,â€ the law
  implies that it is to be done within a reasonable time. In equity, strict
  compliance with time limits contained in a contract will not ordinarily be enforced,
  except with regard to option contracts. 

Faulkner v. Millar, 319 S.C. 216, 219-20, 460 S.E.2d 378, 380 (1995)
  (citations omitted).
The
  determination of whether Bradfordâ€™s actions constituted waiver is a question of
  fact.Â  See Hobgood v. Pennington, 300 S.C. 309, 314, 387 S.E.2d
  690, 693 (Ct. App. 1989) (â€œWhere time is not originally of the essence, it may
  be made so by one party giving notice to the other that he will insist on
  performance by a certain date, provided the time allowed by the notice is
  reasonable, which is a question of fact for the jury depending on the
  circumstances of the particular case.â€);Â  Atkinson v. Atkinson, 279 S.C.
  454, 455, 309 S.E.2d 14, 15 (Ct. App. 1983) (stating a finding of fact depends
  on a courtâ€™s decision of â€œwhether a certain event either did or did not occur
  or that a particular circumstance either did or did not exist.â€)Â  Therefore,
  the issue before us is whether the trial courtâ€™s finding, that Bradfordâ€™s conduct waived strict compliance, is reasonably supported by evidence contained
  in the record.Â  Epworth Childrenâ€™s Home v. Beasley, 365 S.C. 157, 164,
  616 S.E.2d 710, 714 (2005).Â  We find the record contains such support.Â  
Although
  the Contract stated the â€œClosing Date shall be October 15, 2002,â€ it did not indicate
  time was of the essence.Â  Additionally, the Contract stated, â€œ[b]uyer shall
  notify Seller or listing agent in writing, by 12:00 noon 10 days from date
  Buyer is notified house is complete of any deficiencies revealed by
  inspection.â€Â  The Bradfords entered into the Contract understanding a lot of
  work still needed to be completed on the House.Â Â Â  Furthermore, Clyde Madren
  testified he told the Bradfords, â€œ[W]ith any renovation, when you get into it,
  you donâ€™t know what youâ€™re going to find beyond the next wall, and there, there
  could be some slow downs.â€Â  From the beginning the Bradfords knew the
  completion of the renovations would actually set the closing date.Â  
Numerous
  emails between the parties also evidence the agreed upon changes in the closing
  dates.Â  In one particular example, on October 21, 2002, seven days after the
  closing date of the Contract, Bradford emailed Nancy Madren after his mortgage
  companyâ€™s appraiser had not finished the appraisal.Â  Bradford wrote, â€œ[i]n
  light of this, doesnâ€™t look like we can close this week.Â  Monday the 28th is the earliest target.â€Â  In another email Bradford wrote, â€œ[w]hen you have a
  schedule for finishing the remaining items, please furnish it, and your estimated
    closing date so we can set up another.â€ (emphasis added).Â  On October 31,
  2002, the Madrens notified Bradford the renovations were complete and the house
  was ready for a walk-through.Â  In response, Bradford sent an email stating he
  and his wife decided against purchasing the House. Â By this time, the Madrens
  had complied with Bradfordâ€™s many renovation requests.Â  Consequently, Bradfordâ€™s own requests further delayed the closing date. 
We
  hold the aforementioned evidence reasonably supports the trial courtâ€™s finding
  that Bradfordâ€™s conduct modified the closing date in his real estate contract
  with the Madrens.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling.Â  
III.  Amount of Damages
Bradford contends the trial court erred in awarding damages of
  $55,000 to the Madrens.Â  Bradford argues the figure was not supported by sufficient evidence and was instead based
  on surmise and speculation.Â  We disagree.Â  
When calculating
  damages for breach of contract, damages should place a nonbreaching party in
  the position he would have enjoyed had the contract been performed.Â  Collins
    Entmâ€™t., Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 559, 611 S.E.2d 262, 268-69 (Ct. App.
  2005).Â  Generally, damages will consist of â€œ(1) out-of-pocket costs actually
  incurred as a result of the contract; and (2) the gain above costs that would
  have been realized had the contract been performed.â€ Id. at 559, 611
  S.E.2d at 269.Â  Though a party need not prove damages with mathematical
  certainty, the evidence should allow a court to reasonably determine an
  appropriate amount.Â  Yadkin Brick Co. v. Materials Recovery Co., 339 S.C. 640, 646, 529 S.E.2d 764, 767 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Furthermore, an amount of
  damages cannot be left to conjecture, guess, or speculation.Â  Collins,
  363 S.C. at 559, 611 S.E.2d at 269.
In
  the present action, Clyde Madren testified the couple invested $40,000 of labor and materials into the home.Â  Madren also
  testified he and his wife purchased the
  entire tract of land for $82,000 and subdivided it into three separate parcels, one of
  which contained the House.Â  Of the
  $82,000 originally spent to purchase the single tract, Madren attributed $25,000
  of the purchase price to the Raysor Street house.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order explained the $55,000 in damages was calculated
  by subtracting the Madrensâ€™ original purchase price for the House ($25,000) and
  the Madrensâ€™ estimated cost of labor and materials ($40,000) from the
  Contractâ€™s purchase price of the House ($120,000). 
Additionally, Bradford argues Clyde Madren arbitrarily assigned the $25,000 purchase price to the Raysor Street home, and consequently the $55,000 in damages is without basis.Â  However, Bradford offered no evidence for the value of the House when it was purchased by the
  Madrens, so he cannot now protest the trial courtâ€™s adoption of Madrenâ€™s value,
  as it was the only value offered to the court.Â  Hough v. Hough, 312 S.C.
  344, 347, 440 S.E.2d 387, 389 (Ct. App. 1994) (holding a husband who failed to
  present any evidence on issue of valuation of marital estate could not complain
  on appeal that trial court erred in its valuation of the estate).
We
  find the trial court properly calculated damages based on the criteria set
  forth in Collins, 363 S.C. at 559, 611 S.E.2d at 268-9.Â  Additionally,
  we believe Clyde Madrenâ€™s testimony amounted to evidence from which the trial court
  could reasonably determine an appropriate damage award under Yadkin, 339
  S.C. at 646, 529 S.E.2d at 767.Â  â€œIn a law case tried without a jury, questions
  regarding credibility and weight of evidence are exclusively for the trial
  judge.â€Â  Sheek v. Crimestoppers Alarm Systems, 297 S.C. 375, 377, 377
  S.E.2d 132, 133 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  We therefore defer to the trial courtâ€™s
  decision to believe Clyde Madrenâ€™s testimony regarding financial figures and
  use those figures in calculating damages.Â  
Accordingly,
  the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and
KITTREDGE J., concur.


[1] The Madrens later abandoned their specific
performance claim because the House was in foreclosure.Â  
[2] Miriam Bradford passed away before the trial of this
action. 
[3] Bradfordâ€™s counsel at trial differed from his counsel
on appeal.Â  
[4] This court may affirm the trial court based on any
grounds found in the record.Â  Rule 220(c), SCACR; Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 418, 526 S.E.2d 716, 722 (2000).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Vortex Sports
      & Entertainment, Inc., Respondent/Appellant,
				v.
				R. David Ware;
      Ware & Associates, Inc.; Constangy, Brooks & Smith, L.L.C.; and CSMG,
      Inc., Defendants,
				of whom:
				CSMG, Inc., is
      the Appellant/Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court
Judge
Opinion No. 4380
Heard April 8, 2008 â€“ Filed April 28, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Frank R. Ellerbe, III, and Rachel G. Peavy, both of Columbia; Sonya D. Naar and Steven Hunter, both of Chicago, for Appellant/Respondent.
				A. Camden Lewis, Keith M. Babcock, and Ariail E. King, all of Columbia, for Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	

SHORT, J.:Â  In
  this cross-appeal from a tort action, CSMG, Inc., appeals the trial
  courtâ€™s (1) failure to grant its directed verdict motions; (2) admission of
  expert testimony; and (3) admission of speculative damages evidence.Â  Vortex Sports & Entertainment, Inc.,
  (Vortex) appeals the trial courtâ€™s set-off of its award with its settlement
  with R. David Ware.Â  We affirm.
FACTS

Vortex, formed in 2000 in Columbia, South Carolina, is a sports agency corporation.Â  Ware and Bralyn Bennett each
  owned one-third of Vortex, and Terry Williams and Walt Gee each owned one-sixth.Â 
  Ware was the President of Vortexâ€™s Team Sports Division and served as Vortexâ€™s
  attorney.Â  Vortex did not issue any stock or formalize the corporation in
  writing.Â  Vortexâ€™s clients were primarily National Football League (NFL) players
  to whom it provided financial, legal, and marketing assistance.Â  The owners
  agreed Bennett would be the only paid employee and the other owners would be
  paid once Vortex made a profit.Â  
In the
  NFL, sports agents and players enter into Standard Representation Agreements
  (SRAs).Â  SRAs permit an agent to negotiate on the playerâ€™s behalf. Â Under NFL
  policy, SRAs can only be signed by the agent.Â  Industry custom includes agents who
  verbally assign their SRAs to the companies with whom they are affiliated.Â  An SRA
  generally includes a â€œcompensation for serviceâ€ clause entitling the agent to a
  certain percentage of the playerâ€™s compensation in exchange for the agentâ€™s
  services in negotiating the contract.Â  The NFL limits the agentâ€™s maximum
  compensation to three percent.Â  A player may terminate an SRA with five daysâ€™
  notice to the agent.Â  NFL teams do not give players guaranteed contracts, and
  thus, agentsâ€™ fees are not guaranteed. 
Bennett
  and Ware were Vortexâ€™s sports agents.Â  When Vortex began operating, Bennett represented
  three players and Ware represented one player.Â  When those players were paid,
  Vortex would receive the agentâ€™s fees.Â  Â Vortex pledged the income stream from
  all of its SRAs as collateral for its bank loans.Â  
In 2001,
  Vortex signed five new clients.Â  By spring of 2003, Vortex had twenty clients,
  including Terence Newman of the Dallas Cowboys and Clinton Portis of the
  Washington Redskins.Â  Vortex anticipated earning $400,000 to $500,000 solely
  from Newmanâ€™s contract.Â  Vortex, however, was still a fledging company with a
  substantial amount of debt to service.Â  It was not yet profitable and Bennett
  no longer received an annual salary.
In 2003, Ware began negotiating, on Vortexâ€™s
  behalf, with CSMG, an Illinois sports agency that was considering acquiring
  Vortex.Â  Vortex believed CSMG would provide marketing services for Vortexâ€™s
  clients but Vortex would continue providing contract negotiations.Â  However,
  this never came to fruition.Â  Unbeknowst to Vortex, CSMG began negotiating with
  Ware for him to leave Vortex and join CSMG with his Vortex clients.Â  Ultimately,
  Ware began working for CSMG while he was still an officer, shareholder, and
  attorney for Vortex.
CSMG agreed to pay Ware a signing bonus of
  $200,000 and an annual salary of $150,000.Â  Additionally, Ware would receive
  half of the revenues collected from players with whom he had signed SRAs.Â  Once
  Ware left Vortex for CSMG, less than half of Vortexâ€™s twenty clients stayed
  with Vortex, while the others left for CSMG or other agencies. 
Vortex filed suit against: (1) Ware; (2) CSMG;
  (3) Constangy, Brooks & Smith, Wareâ€™s law firm for the majority of the time
  he served as Vortexâ€™s attorney; and (4) Ware and Associates, Wareâ€™s law firm
  when he first became Vortexâ€™s attorney.Â  The causes of action against CSMG
  included aiding and abetting a breach of fiduciary duty and tortious
  interference with a contract.Â  Prior to trial, Vortex settled with all parties
  except CSMG.Â  
At trial, CSMG moved for directed verdicts
  on aiding and abetting a breach of fiduciary duty and tortious interference
  with a contract.Â  The trial court denied the motions.Â  Ultimately, the jury
  found for Vortex on both of those causes of action.[1] Â The jury awarded Vortex $2,200,000
  in actual damages and $500,000 in punitive damages.Â  The trial court reduced Vortexâ€™s
  award by the settlements received from the other defendants.Â  This appeal
  followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. CSMGâ€™s Appeal
A.Â 
  Directed Verdict
CSMG
  argues the trial court erred in denying its directed verdict motions.Â  We
  disagree.
When ruling on a directed verdict motion, the trial court is required
  to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom
  in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  
Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â 
  This court must follow the same standard.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342
  S.C. 279, 299, 536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000). Â â€œIf more
  than one reasonable inference can be drawn or if the inferences to be drawn
  from the evidence are in doubt, the case should be submitted to the jury.â€Â  
Chaney v. Burgess, 246 S.C. 261, 266, 143 S.E.2d
  521, 523 (1965). Â This court will only reverse the circuit
  court when no evidence supports its ruling.Â  Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t
    of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142,
  148 (1999).
1.Â  Aiding and Abetting a Breach of Fiduciary Duty
CSMG argues the trial court erred in denying its
  motion for a directed verdict on Vortexâ€™s aiding and abetting a breach of fiduciary
  duty cause of action because Vortex offered no evidence from which a jury could
  find CSMG knowingly assisted and participated in Wareâ€™s breach.Â  We disagree.
The
  elements for the cause of action of aiding and abetting a breach of fiduciary
  duty are: (1) a breach of a fiduciary duty owed to the plaintiff; (2) the
  defendantâ€™s knowing participation in the breach; and (3) damages. Â Future
    Group, II v. Nationsbank, 324 S.C. 89, 99, 478 S.E.2d 45, 50 (1996).Â 
  â€œThe gravamen of the claim is the defendantâ€™s knowing participation in the
  fiduciaryâ€™s breach.â€Â  Id.
The trial court ruled Ware owed Vortex a fiduciary
  duty.Â  Vortex presented evidence CSMG encouraged Ware not to pay Vortex the
  money he received on SRAs he signed before he left for CSMG.Â  Ware emailed
  David Schwartz, CSMGâ€™s senior vice-president and general counsel, stating:

	I
  realize that our deal is a little different since CSMG wants all my clients and
  the fees due to me but is not assuming the debt of VORTEX.Â  Although I donâ€™t
  wholly own VORTEX I still have to pay the debt but I have no problem giving
  CSMG any fees that I am entitled to. 

Schwartz responded: â€œI have
  added language which will, in a sense, give your guarantee that you will make
  CSMG whole if there are third-party claimants to the fees paid or owed by your
  clients, so weâ€™re willing to dump the whole asset purchase agreement.â€Â  The
  language Schwartz referred to was a clause in CSMGâ€™s employment agreement with
  Ware, which stated:

	As
  consideration for entering into this Employment Agreement, [CSMG] expects to
  receive the fees currently owed to [Ware] by the clients set forth on Exhibit A
  [Vortexâ€™s Clients], as well as future fees that will be owed by such clients. .
  . .Â  [Ware] agrees that if any fees due to be paid . . . are diminished or
  delayed because a third party claims entitlement to such fees, or because the
  client contends the fees are owed to a third party, then [Ware] shall promptly
  pay to [CSMG] an amount that would make [CSMG] whole . . . .â€Â  

Marty Pereira, CSMGâ€™s Executive
  Vice-President and Chief Financial Officer, stated in an email: â€œAfter having a
  couple of conversations with [Ware], I think I have [him] convinced that he
  should not pay off the loan, in any manner, until some kind of agreement is
  reached with Vortex.â€ Â We note CSMG originally approached Vortex seeking
  to acquire the entire company, and later, enter into a collaborative venture,
  but ultimately decided only to hire Ware, who held the majority of Vortexâ€™s
  SRAs.Â  
CSMG
  argues it had no actual knowledge of Wareâ€™s breach of fiduciary duties to
  Vortex nor did it substantially assist Ware with the breach.Â  However, Vortex
  presented evidence CSMG knew Ware was one of several partners and the attorney
  for Vortex, not simply an employee.Â  There is also evidence CSMG knew Ware had
  certain financial obligations to Vortex, even if he was no longer an employee.Â 
  Therefore, there is evidence CSMG had actual knowledge Ware owed a fiduciary
  duty to Vortex.Â  Further, there is evidence CSMG knowingly encouraged Ware to breach
  that duty because there is evidence it encouraged Ware to withhold the SRA fees
  from Vortex.Â  Accordingly, because Vortex presented evidence CSMG aided and
  abetted in a breach of fiduciary duty, the trial court did not err in denying
  the directed verdict motion.
2.Â  Tortious Interference with a Contract 
CSMG next contends
  the trial court erred in denying its motion for a directed verdict on Vortexâ€™s
  tortious interference with a contract action because Vortex presented no
  evidence CSMG: (1) knew of Vortexâ€™s contract with Ware; (2) knew hiring Ware
  interfered with that contract; or (3) lacked justification to hire Ware.Â  We
  disagree.
â€œThe
  elements of a cause of action for tortious interference with contract are: (1)
